declare module 'astro:content' {
	interface Render {
		'.mdx': Promise<{
			Content: import('astro').MDXContent;
			headings: import('astro').MarkdownHeading[];
			remarkPluginFrontmatter: Record<string, any>;
			components: import('astro').MDXInstance<{}>['components'];
		}>;
	}
}

declare module 'astro:content' {
	export interface RenderResult {
		Content: import('astro/runtime/server/index.js').AstroComponentFactory;
		headings: import('astro').MarkdownHeading[];
		remarkPluginFrontmatter: Record<string, any>;
	}
	interface Render {
		'.md': Promise<RenderResult>;
	}

	export interface RenderedContent {
		html: string;
		metadata?: {
			imagePaths: Array<string>;
			[key: string]: unknown;
		};
	}
}

declare module 'astro:content' {
	type Flatten<T> = T extends { [K: string]: infer U } ? U : never;

	export type CollectionKey = keyof AnyEntryMap;
	export type CollectionEntry<C extends CollectionKey> = Flatten<AnyEntryMap[C]>;

	export type ContentCollectionKey = keyof ContentEntryMap;
	export type DataCollectionKey = keyof DataEntryMap;

	type AllValuesOf<T> = T extends any ? T[keyof T] : never;
	type ValidContentEntrySlug<C extends keyof ContentEntryMap> = AllValuesOf<
		ContentEntryMap[C]
	>['slug'];

	export type ReferenceDataEntry<
		C extends CollectionKey,
		E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C] = string,
	> = {
		collection: C;
		id: E;
	};
	export type ReferenceContentEntry<
		C extends keyof ContentEntryMap,
		E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C> | (string & {}) = string,
	> = {
		collection: C;
		slug: E;
	};
	export type ReferenceLiveEntry<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']> = {
		collection: C;
		id: string;
	};

	/** @deprecated Use `getEntry` instead. */
	export function getEntryBySlug<
		C extends keyof ContentEntryMap,
		E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C> | (string & {}),
	>(
		collection: C,
		// Note that this has to accept a regular string too, for SSR
		entrySlug: E,
	): E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C>
		? Promise<CollectionEntry<C>>
		: Promise<CollectionEntry<C> | undefined>;

	/** @deprecated Use `getEntry` instead. */
	export function getDataEntryById<C extends keyof DataEntryMap, E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C]>(
		collection: C,
		entryId: E,
	): Promise<CollectionEntry<C>>;

	export function getCollection<C extends keyof AnyEntryMap, E extends CollectionEntry<C>>(
		collection: C,
		filter?: (entry: CollectionEntry<C>) => entry is E,
	): Promise<E[]>;
	export function getCollection<C extends keyof AnyEntryMap>(
		collection: C,
		filter?: (entry: CollectionEntry<C>) => unknown,
	): Promise<CollectionEntry<C>[]>;

	export function getLiveCollection<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']>(
		collection: C,
		filter?: LiveLoaderCollectionFilterType<C>,
	): Promise<
		import('astro').LiveDataCollectionResult<LiveLoaderDataType<C>, LiveLoaderErrorType<C>>
	>;

	export function getEntry<
		C extends keyof ContentEntryMap,
		E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C> | (string & {}),
	>(
		entry: ReferenceContentEntry<C, E>,
	): E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C>
		? Promise<CollectionEntry<C>>
		: Promise<CollectionEntry<C> | undefined>;
	export function getEntry<
		C extends keyof DataEntryMap,
		E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C] | (string & {}),
	>(
		entry: ReferenceDataEntry<C, E>,
	): E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C]
		? Promise<DataEntryMap[C][E]>
		: Promise<CollectionEntry<C> | undefined>;
	export function getEntry<
		C extends keyof ContentEntryMap,
		E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C> | (string & {}),
	>(
		collection: C,
		slug: E,
	): E extends ValidContentEntrySlug<C>
		? Promise<CollectionEntry<C>>
		: Promise<CollectionEntry<C> | undefined>;
	export function getEntry<
		C extends keyof DataEntryMap,
		E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C] | (string & {}),
	>(
		collection: C,
		id: E,
	): E extends keyof DataEntryMap[C]
		? string extends keyof DataEntryMap[C]
			? Promise<DataEntryMap[C][E]> | undefined
			: Promise<DataEntryMap[C][E]>
		: Promise<CollectionEntry<C> | undefined>;
	export function getLiveEntry<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']>(
		collection: C,
		filter: string | LiveLoaderEntryFilterType<C>,
	): Promise<import('astro').LiveDataEntryResult<LiveLoaderDataType<C>, LiveLoaderErrorType<C>>>;

	/** Resolve an array of entry references from the same collection */
	export function getEntries<C extends keyof ContentEntryMap>(
		entries: ReferenceContentEntry<C, ValidContentEntrySlug<C>>[],
	): Promise<CollectionEntry<C>[]>;
	export function getEntries<C extends keyof DataEntryMap>(
		entries: ReferenceDataEntry<C, keyof DataEntryMap[C]>[],
	): Promise<CollectionEntry<C>[]>;

	export function render<C extends keyof AnyEntryMap>(
		entry: AnyEntryMap[C][string],
	): Promise<RenderResult>;

	export function reference<C extends keyof AnyEntryMap>(
		collection: C,
	): import('astro/zod').ZodEffects<
		import('astro/zod').ZodString,
		C extends keyof ContentEntryMap
			? ReferenceContentEntry<C, ValidContentEntrySlug<C>>
			: ReferenceDataEntry<C, keyof DataEntryMap[C]>
	>;
	// Allow generic `string` to avoid excessive type errors in the config
	// if `dev` is not running to update as you edit.
	// Invalid collection names will be caught at build time.
	export function reference<C extends string>(
		collection: C,
	): import('astro/zod').ZodEffects<import('astro/zod').ZodString, never>;

	type ReturnTypeOrOriginal<T> = T extends (...args: any[]) => infer R ? R : T;
	type InferEntrySchema<C extends keyof AnyEntryMap> = import('astro/zod').infer<
		ReturnTypeOrOriginal<Required<ContentConfig['collections'][C]>['schema']>
	>;

	type ContentEntryMap = {
		
	};

	type DataEntryMap = {
		"posts": Record<string, {
  id: string;
  render(): Render[".md"];
  slug: string;
  body: string;
  collection: "posts";
  data: InferEntrySchema<"posts">;
  rendered?: RenderedContent;
  filePath?: string;
}>;
"projects": Record<string, {
  id: string;
  render(): Render[".md"];
  slug: string;
  body: string;
  collection: "projects";
  data: InferEntrySchema<"projects">;
  rendered?: RenderedContent;
  filePath?: string;
}>;

	};

	type AnyEntryMap = ContentEntryMap & DataEntryMap;

	type ExtractLoaderTypes<T> = T extends import('astro/loaders').LiveLoader<
		infer TData,
		infer TEntryFilter,
		infer TCollectionFilter,
		infer TError
	>
		? { data: TData; entryFilter: TEntryFilter; collectionFilter: TCollectionFilter; error: TError }
		: { data: never; entryFilter: never; collectionFilter: never; error: never };
	type ExtractDataType<T> = ExtractLoaderTypes<T>['data'];
	type ExtractEntryFilterType<T> = ExtractLoaderTypes<T>['entryFilter'];
	type ExtractCollectionFilterType<T> = ExtractLoaderTypes<T>['collectionFilter'];
	type ExtractErrorType<T> = ExtractLoaderTypes<T>['error'];

	type LiveLoaderDataType<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']> =
		LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['schema'] extends undefined
			? ExtractDataType<LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['loader']>
			: import('astro/zod').infer<
					Exclude<LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['schema'], undefined>
				>;
	type LiveLoaderEntryFilterType<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']> =
		ExtractEntryFilterType<LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['loader']>;
	type LiveLoaderCollectionFilterType<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']> =
		ExtractCollectionFilterType<LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['loader']>;
	type LiveLoaderErrorType<C extends keyof LiveContentConfig['collections']> = ExtractErrorType<
		LiveContentConfig['collections'][C]['loader']
	>;

	export type ContentConfig = typeof import("../src/content/config.js");
	export type LiveContentConfig = never;
}

A GDExtension plugin that hooks PyTorch into Godot's rendering pipeline via C++, and everything that went wrong along the way.",[17,18,19,20],"c++","pytorch","godot","ml",["Date","2024-12-15T00:00:00.000Z"],true,"https://github.com/ethereal-keys/Godot-Style-Transfer",1,[26,29,32,35,38],{"label":27,"id":28},"./the-problem","the-problem",{"label":30,"id":31},"./the-model","the-model",{"label":33,"id":34},"./the-bridge","the-bridge",{"label":36,"id":37},"./the-paradox","the-paradox",{"label":39,"id":40},"./reflections","reflections","## The Problem\n\nI wanted to make a game look like a painting in real-time. Not a static\nfilter, not a post-process shader pretending to be painterly. Actual neural\nstyle transfer, running live inside a game engine at playable framerates.\n\n\u003CYouTubeEmbed videoId=\"ad-yBz3aguA\" title=\"Style Transfer Demo: Oral Presentation with Brief Demo\" />\n\n*A walkthrough of the architecture and results, with a brief demo at the end.*\n\nThe rest of this page is the long version.\n\n### The Baseline: 45 Seconds Per Frame\n\nI started where anyone would: the original Gatys et al. paper. The idea is\nbeautiful. You take a content image and a style image, then iteratively\noptimize the pixels until the output looks like the content *painted in* the style.\n\n```python\ndef style_transfer(content, style, iterations=500):\n    # This took 45 seconds per frame\n    for i in range(iterations):\n        optimize_step(content, style)\n    return content\n```\n\nThe results were gorgeous. The performance was not.\n\n45 seconds. Per frame. For a game targeting 60fps, I needed to be roughly\n2,700 times faster.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/compiling.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 303: Compiling\"\n  caption=\"Me, waiting 45 seconds per frame, telling myself it's 'research time.'\"\n/>\n\n### The Fix: Don't Optimize at Runtime\n\nThe breakthrough came from Johnson et al.'s feed-forward approach. Instead of\nrunning 500 optimization steps per frame, you train a neural network *once* to\nperform the style transformation in a single forward pass.\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The Speedup\">\n{`\n  Gatys et al. (2016):              Johnson et al. (2016):\n\n  ┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐\n  │  Input   │                      │  Input   │\n  │  Frame   │                      │  Frame   │\n  └────┬─────┘                      └────┬─────┘\n       │                                 │\n       ▼                                 ▼\n  ┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐\n  │ 500 iters│                      │  Single  │\n  │ of VGG   │                      │ Forward  │\n  │ backprop │                      │  Pass    │\n  └────┬─────┘                      └────┬─────┘\n       │                                 │\n  ~45 seconds                        ~16ms\n       │                                 │\n       ▼                                 ▼\n  ┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐\n  │ Stylized │                      │ Stylized │\n  │  Output  │                      │  Output  │\n  └──────────┘                      └──────────┘\n\n  Beautiful but slow.               Fast enough for games.\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe tradeoff: you lose flexibility (one trained network per style) but gain\nreal-time performance. For a game engine plugin, that's exactly the right deal.\n\nNow I just had to build it, train it, export it to C++, link it against\nlibtorch, compile it as a GDExtension shared library, and hook it into\nGodot's rendering pipeline. Starting from this:\n\n\u003CImageShowcase\n  featured=\"/images/style-transfer/og_game.png\"\n  featuredLabel=\"the starting point, a crisp pixel-art platformer\"\n  images={[]}\n  caption=\"the little robot, blissfully unaware it's about to become a Van Gogh\"\n/>\n\n## The Model\n\nBoth model variants are *tiny*. The slim model is **110kB** on disk.\nThe normal model is **196kB**. For reference, the JPEG header image\non most blog posts is bigger than the entire neural network.\n\n### Architecture\n\nBoth follow an encoder-residual-decoder pattern with only **16 channels**\nthroughout, compared to the 128 channels in Johnson et al.'s original.\nThe key difference between variants is depth:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"Slim vs Normal\">\n{`\n  Slim (110kB, 1 res block):         Normal (196kB, 5 res blocks):\n\n  Input (3ch)                        Input (3ch)\n      │                                  │\n      ▼                                  ▼\n  ┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐\n  │ Conv 3→16  │ ×3 layers           │ Conv 3→16  │ ×3 layers\n  │ stride 1,2,2                     │ stride 1,2,2\n  │ IN + ReLU6 │                     │ IN + ReLU6 │\n  └─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘\n        │                                  │\n        ▼                                  ▼\n  ┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐\n  │  1× Res    │                     │  5× Res    │\n  │   Block    │                     │  Blocks    │\n  └─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘\n        │                                  │\n        ▼                                  ▼\n  ┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐\n  │ Upsample   │ ×2 + final conv    │ Upsample   │ ×2 + final conv\n  │ 16→16→3    │                     │ 16→16→3    │\n  └─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘\n        │                                  │\n        ▼                                  ▼\n  Output (3ch)                       Output (3ch)\n\n  57kB VRAM  ·  52 FPS               129kB VRAM  ·  47 FPS\n          (at 600×400)                        (at 600×400)\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe choice of ReLU6 over standard ReLU is a mobile-optimization trick;\nit clamps activations to [0, 6], which helps with quantization stability.\nInstanceNorm with affine parameters handles the style-specific normalization.\n\n### Training\n\nTrained on Pascal VOC 2012 (~11,500 natural images) for content, with\nfour style images: Monet, Udnie, Mosaic, and Van Gogh's Starry Night.\n5 epochs, Adam optimizer, learning rate 1e-3.\n\nThe loss function is where style transfer gets interesting. We use a\npre-trained VGG-16 as a \"perceptual judge\":\n\n**L_total = α·L_content + β·L_style + γ·L_tv**\n\nWith weights: `style_weight = 1e5`, `content_weight = 1e0`, `tv_weight = 1e-7`.\n\nThat style weight is 100,000× the content weight. You're basically telling\nthe network: *\"I care about looking like Van Gogh way more than I care about\nlooking like the original scene.\"*\n\nThe mathematical heart of style transfer is the Gram matrix, which captures\ntexture statistics by computing correlations between feature channels:\n\n```python\ndef gram(x):\n    (bs, ch, h, w) = x.size()\n    f = x.view(bs, ch, w*h)\n    f_T = f.transpose(1, 2)\n    G = f.bmm(f_T) / (ch * h * w)\n    return G\n```\n\nFour lines. That's what makes a photograph look like a painting.\n\n### Key Modifications\n\nThe original model was hardcoded for 256×256 inputs, useless for a game\nwith a dynamic viewport. I refactored it to be fully convolutional, replacing\nhardcoded dimensions with relative scaling factors in the upsampling layers.\nAfter training, models were exported to TorchScript via `torch.jit.trace`\nand optimized with `torch.jit.optimize_for_inference()` for the C++ side.\n\nI also evaluated both models against ~8,000 screenshots from MAME console\ngames, because if you're building this for game engines, you should probably\ntest on actual game content, not just photos of dogs.\n\n## The Bridge\n\nThis is where it gets hairy. The goal: make a PyTorch model run inside\nGodot's render loop, every frame, without the engine noticing.\n\n### The Scene Setup\n\nThe Godot scene is deceptively simple:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"game_viewport.tscn\">\n{`\n  Node2D (root)\n    │\n    ├── Game (SubViewport)           ← the actual game runs here\n    │     size: 512×256                 renders to a texture\n    │\n    ├── Sprite2D                     ← displays the stylized output\n    │     position: (512, 299)\n    │\n    ├── MyCustomNode (GDExtension)   ← the magic middleman\n    │     viewport_path: ../Game\n    │     display_sprite_path: ../Sprite2D\n    │\n    └── Sprite2D2                    ← small preview of original\n          texture: ViewportTexture(Game)\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe GDScript that wires it up is exactly three lines:\n\n```gdscript\nextends MyCustomNode\n\nfunc _ready():\n    set(\"viewport_path\", NodePath(\"../Game\"))\n    set(\"display_sprite_path\", NodePath(\"../Sprite2D\"))\n```\n\nEverything else happens in C++.\n\n### The C++ Pipeline\n\nEvery frame, `_process` grabs the viewport texture, runs it through\nthe model, and pushes the result back. Here's the core of `process_image`,\nstripped of debug logging:\n\n```cpp\n// 1. Convert RGBA → RGB\nprocessed_image->convert(Image::FORMAT_RGB8);\n\n// 2. Borrow Godot's pixel data (no copy!)\nPackedByteArray data = processed_image->get_data();\ntorch::Tensor tensor = torch::from_blob(\n    const_cast\u003Cvoid*>(static_cast\u003Cconst void*>(data.ptr())),\n    {height, width, 3}, torch::kUInt8\n).to(torch::kFloat32);\n\n// 3. Normalize with ImageNet stats\ntensor = tensor / 255.0f;\ntensor = tensor.permute({2, 0, 1}).unsqueeze(0);  // HWC → NCHW\ntensor = (tensor - mean_tensor.view({1,3,1,1}))\n       / std_tensor.view({1,3,1,1});\n\n// 4. GPU transfer + inference\nif (torch::cuda::is_available())\n    tensor = tensor.to(torch::kCUDA);\ntorch::Tensor output = model.forward({tensor}).toTensor();\n\n// 5. Denormalize and copy back to Godot\noutput = output * std_tensor.view({3,1,1})\n       + mean_tensor.view({3,1,1});\noutput = output.clamp(0, 1) * 255.0f;\noutput = output.to(torch::kUInt8)\n               .permute({1, 2, 0}).contiguous();  // NCHW → HWC\n\nmemcpy(out_data.ptrw(), output.data_ptr\u003Cuint8_t>(),\n       width * height * 3);\n```\n\nThat `torch::from_blob` on line 5 is borrowing memory directly from\nGodot's `PackedByteArray`. No copy. The tensor just points at Godot's\npixel buffer. It's efficient and also slightly terrifying: if the\n`PackedByteArray` gets garbage collected while the tensor is alive,\nyou're reading freed memory. In practice it's fine because the tensor\nis consumed within the same function scope. But it's the kind of thing\nthat keeps you up at night.\n\n### The Build System Nightmare\n\nCompiling a shared library that links against *both* godot-cpp and\nlibtorch is an exercise in patience. The SConstruct file has paths like:\n\n```python\nenv.Append(CPPPATH=[\n    '/home/sushanth/Dev/libtorch/include',\n    '/home/sushanth/Dev/libtorch/include/torch/csrc/api/include'\n])\nenv.Append(LINKFLAGS=[\n    '-Wl,-rpath,/home/sushanth/Dev/libtorch/lib',\n])\n```\n\nYes, those are hardcoded absolute paths to my machine. Yes, this means\nnobody else can build it without editing the source. This is my `heirarchy`\nvariable, the thing I'll cringe at in three years but can't deny shipped\nthe project on time.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/dependency.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 2347: Dependency\"\n  caption=\"The entire plugin's portability, held together by one developer's /home directory.\"\n/>\n\nThe CUDA story was even worse. Getting cuDNN to cooperate with both\nlibtorch and Godot's OpenGL context required solving dependency conflicts\nthat would make a package manager weep. We eventually got GPU acceleration\nworking, but it was the single biggest time sink of the project.\n\n## The Paradox\n\nHere's where it gets interesting. We trained both models, benchmarked them\ncarefully, and discovered something that contradicts what you'd expect.\n\n### The Numbers\n\n\u003CDataTable caption=\"Model Benchmark Results\">\n\n| Metric | Slim Model | Normal Model |\n|--------|-----------|--------------| \n| **Disk Size** | 110 kB | 196 kB |\n| **VRAM Usage** | 57 kB | 129 kB |\n| **FPS** (600×400) | 52 | 47 |\n| **SSIM** (structural similarity) | 0.3047 | 0.2789 |\n| **LPIPS** (perceptual quality) | 0.6055 | 0.6125 |\n\n\u003C/DataTable>\n\nThe normal model (five residual blocks, nearly double the parameters)\nachieves **lower total test loss** (17.79 vs. 21.05). By every training\nmetric, it's the better model.\n\nBut the slim model has **higher SSIM** and **less temporal flickering**\nin actual gameplay.\n\nThe mathematically \"better\" model looks worse in practice.\n\n### Why the Dumber Model Wins\n\nThe training-test gap tells the story. The slim model's style loss jumps\nfrom 2.00 (train) to 8.27 (test), a big generalization gap. The normal\nmodel is tighter: 1.64 to 4.71. Conventional wisdom says the normal model\ngeneralizes better.\n\nBut in a game running at 60fps, **temporal consistency matters more than\nper-frame quality**. The slim model's simpler architecture produces more\nconsistent frame-to-frame outputs. The normal model's extra capacity lets\nit be more \"creative\" with each frame, which means more flickering when\nthe scene changes slightly between frames.\n\nThis is a genuinely useful insight: **optimization metrics during training\ndon't always align with quality in dynamic, real-time applications.** Static\nimage loss functions can't capture what it feels like to watch a game\nwhere the art style jitters every frame.\n\n### The Styles\n\nI trained both models on four artistic styles: Van Gogh's Starry Night\nfor swirling expressionism, Monet for soft impressionistic pastels, Udnie\nfor bold abstract patterns, and Mosaic for tile-like geometric segmentation.\n\nAll four produced visually distinct results on the 2D platformer demo.\n\n\u003CImageShowcase\n  featured=\"/images/style-transfer/og_game.png\"\n  featuredLabel=\"original\"\n  columns={4}\n  images={[\n    { src: \"/images/style-transfer/monet.png\", label: \"monet\" },\n    { src: \"/images/style-transfer/udnie.png\", label: \"udnie\" },\n    { src: \"/images/style-transfer/van_gogh.png\", label: \"van gogh\" },\n    { src: \"/images/style-transfer/mosaic.png\", label: \"mosaic\" },\n  ]}\n  caption=\"same frame, four styles, all running at 50+ FPS on CPU\"\n/>\n\nThe Van Gogh style was the crowd favorite, those coins turning into\nStarry Night orbs is genuinely delightful. The Mosaic style looked\nsurprisingly good on pixel-art-style games.\n\n## Reflections\n\n### What Worked\n\nThe feed-forward architecture was the right call from day one. The fully\nconvolutional refactor for dynamic input sizing was the most important\nsingle modification; without it, the plugin would only work at one fixed\nresolution. The GDExtension API was cleaner than I expected; Godot's\nnode-based architecture mapped naturally onto the capture-process-display\npipeline.\n\nAnd starting with the slim model turned out to be accidentally brilliant.\nI spent time on the normal model assuming more parameters meant better\nresults, then discovered the slim model was better for the actual use case.\nSometimes the simplest architecture wins.\n\n### What's Rough\n\nLet me be honest about the state of this codebase.\n\nThe model path is hardcoded to `/home/sushanth/Dev/SML-Godot/ArtSynapse/model.pth`.\nThe build system has hardcoded paths to my local libtorch installation.\nThe FPS counter prints to stdout on *every single frame*, not every 20\nseconds like the commented-out version suggests. The ONNX export path exists\nbut the inference function literally has a bare `return` with no value.\n\n```python\ndef onnx_infer(path, img):\n    sess = rt.InferenceSession(path)\n    input_name = sess.get_inputs()[0].name\n    out = sess.run(None, {input_name: img.astype(np.float32)})[0]\n    return  # ← this returns None. ask me how I know.\n```\n\nIt's a \"works on my machine\" binary. The cuDNN dependency means\nbuilding it on another system requires exactly the right CUDA toolkit\nversion, the right cuDNN version, and a willingness to read CMake error\nmessages for an afternoon.\n\n### What I'd Do Differently\n\nProfile GPU memory from day one instead of discovering the contention\nbetween Godot's renderer and PyTorch late in the project. Start with\nthe slim model instead of assuming the normal model would be better.\nAnd tackle temporal consistency early; a simple exponential moving\naverage blend between consecutive stylized frames would have reduced\nflickering significantly with minimal performance cost.\n\n### Future Directions\n\n**Dynamic model loading** at runtime, so you could switch styles during\ngameplay without restarting. **Asset-specific styling**: apply style\ntransfer to just the skybox or tilemap rather than the whole viewport.\nA **Colab training notebook** so other developers could train custom\nstyle models without setting up a local PyTorch environment.\n\n### The Thing About Course Projects\n\nThis was built for a Statistical Machine Learning course at ASU. The\nkind of project where the scope starts reasonable and then you find\nyourself debugging CUDA linker errors at 2am because you decided\n\"just hook a neural network into a game engine, how hard can it be?\"\n\nThe model is 110 kilobytes. The build system that compiles it is\nmore complex than most production deployments I've worked on. The\nhardcoded paths are embarrassing. The FPS logging is noisy. The\nONNX export is broken.\n\nBut it runs. A 2D platformer, rendered in Van Gogh's style, at 52 frames\nper second. You can jump, shoot, collect coins, and the whole world\nlooks like a painting.\n\nIt runs. I'll take it.","src/content/projects/style-transfer.mdx","6cf5eb3d44f1a0c1","style-transfer.mdx","swe-bench",{"id":45,"data":47,"body":71,"filePath":72,"digest":73,"legacyId":74,"deferredRender":22},{"title":48,"description":49,"tags":50,"publishedAt":54,"featured":22,"github":55,"order":56,"tabs":57},"What 747 Correct Answers Couldn't Teach a 0.5B Model","We distilled Claude's problem-solving traces into training data for small open-source models. The models responded by outputting special tokens forever. A postmortem on why teaching models to use tools is harder than teaching them to write code.",[51,20,52,53],"python","transformers","nlp",["Date","2025-03-20T00:00:00.000Z"],"https://github.com/ethereal-keys/NLP-Project",3,[58,61,64,67,70],{"label":59,"id":60},"./the-idea","the-idea",{"label":62,"id":63},"./the-pipeline","the-pipeline",{"label":65,"id":66},"./the-wall","the-wall",{"label":68,"id":69},"./the-vindication","the-vindication",{"label":39,"id":40},"## The Idea\n\nSWE-bench asks a simple question: given a real GitHub issue from an open-source\nproject, can an AI produce a working patch?\n\nNot \"write a function.\" Not \"complete this snippet.\" *Navigate a repository\nyou've never seen, find the bug, fix it, and make the tests pass.* The kind\nof task that takes a human developer anywhere from twenty minutes to an\nentire afternoon.\n\nClaude 3.7 Sonnet, paired with the SWE-agent framework, was solving about\n34% of these problems. The open-source alternatives we could actually\nrun on our hardware? Zero. Literally zero.\n\nThe hypothesis was simple: Claude already knows how to solve these\nproblems. It leaves behind a detailed trace of every command it runs,\nevery file it reads, every edit it makes. What if we took those traces\nand used them to *teach* a smaller model the same behavior?\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/physicists.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 793: Physicists\"\n  caption=\"Us, NLP students, looking at software engineering automation: 'It's just fine-tuning.'\"\n/>\n\nThe idea had a name: knowledge distillation. And it had a long track record in ML.\nLarger models teach smaller models all the time. We had the teacher (Claude),\nthe textbook (747 successful solution traces), and the students\n(Qwen2.5-Coder-0.5B and Mistral-7B). We had three 8GB GPUs and access to\nASU's Slurm cluster, which doesn't support Docker, a detail that would\nmatter later.\n\nThis was a group project for CSE 576 (NLP). The team split into parallel\napproaches: agentic fine-tuning, agentless methods, reinforcement learning.\nI owned the agentic function-call fine-tuning: build the dataset from Claude's\ntraces and fine-tune open-source models to reproduce its tool-calling behavior\ninside SWE-agent.\n\nWhat could go wrong?\n\n## The Pipeline\n\nThe data engineering was the best part of this project. I'm saying that\nupfront because the rest of the story goes downhill.\n\n### Source Material\n\nSWE-agent works by giving the model a set of tools (view files, search\ncode, edit files, run tests) and letting it interact with a Docker\ncontainer that has the repository cloned and the issue loaded. Each\nsuccessful run produces a log: a full conversation between the model\nand the environment, from the initial issue description through every\ntool call to the final patch submission.\n\nWe started with 2,276 problem logs from the state-of-the-art run\n(SWE-agent + Claude 3.7 Sonnet on the SWE-bench test set). Of those,\n747 contained valid, test-passing solutions.\n\n### The Processing Pipeline\n\nTurning raw logs into training data was a multi-stage process:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"Dataset Pipeline\">\n{`\n  2,276 raw logs\n      │\n      ▼\n  ┌────────────┐\n  │  filter    │── 1,529 failures discarded\n  │  passing   │\n  └─────┬──────┘\n        │\n        ▼\n  747 successful solution logs\n        │\n        ▼\n  ┌────────────┐\n  │  parse     │── generic commands → structured\n  │  to func   │   function call dictionaries\n  │  calls     │\n  └─────┬──────┘\n        │\n        ▼\n  ┌────────────┐\n  │  add sys   │── system prompts + tool\n  │  prompts   │   specifications injected\n  └─────┬──────┘\n        │\n        ▼\n  ┌────────────┐\n  │  chunk &   │── split at ~4,096 tokens\n  │  dedup     │   remove duplicate tool calls\n  └─────┬──────┘\n        │\n        ▼\n  ~11,000 conversation turns\n  ready for fine-tuning\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nEach entry in the final dataset was a structured conversation: a system\nmessage with tool definitions, followed by alternating assistant\n(model actions) and function (environment responses) turns.\n\n```python\ndef chunk_conversation(messages, max_tokens=4096):\n    \"\"\"Split long solution traces into training-sized chunks.\n    Each chunk preserves the system prompt and maintains\n    conversation coherence.\"\"\"\n    chunks = []\n    current_chunk = [messages[0]]  # always keep system prompt\n    current_tokens = calculate_tokens(messages[0])\n\n    for msg in messages[1:]:\n        msg_tokens = calculate_tokens(msg)\n        if current_tokens + msg_tokens > max_tokens:\n            if len(current_chunk) >= 3:\n                chunks.append(current_chunk)\n            current_chunk = [messages[0]]\n            current_tokens = calculate_tokens(messages[0])\n        current_chunk.append(msg)\n        current_tokens += msg_tokens\n\n    if len(current_chunk) >= 3:\n        chunks.append(current_chunk)\n    return chunks\n```\n\n### What the Data Revealed\n\nAnalysis of the final dataset showed how Claude actually solves problems.\nThe action distribution was telling:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"Agent Action Distribution\">\n{`\n  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n  │  examine file   ████████░░░░░░░░░  23.2%    │\n  │  modify code    ██████████░░░░░░░  26.3%    │\n  │  execute test   ████████████████░  43.4%    │\n  │  other          ██░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░   7.1%    │\n  └─────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\n43% of all actions were test execution. Claude runs tests almost twice as\noften as it modifies code. Successful problem-solving, it turns out, is\nmostly *verification*, not *generation*. The model reads, edits a little,\ntests, reads the output, edits again, tests again. It's methodical.\nPatient. The opposite of what a 0.5B model is good at.\n\nI didn't appreciate that at the time.\n\n\u003CCallout type=\"tip\">\nThe processed dataset is publicly available:\n[**747 Claude SWE-agent Solution Traces → 11,000 Training Turns**](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1V3uEkmLSQ9K4iPg7NJNjUgFjqc9CyI50?usp=sharing).\nIf you're working on SWE-bench fine-tuning, especially with the bash-only\nformat conversion described later, this might save you a few weeks of\npipeline work.\n\u003C/Callout>\n\n## The Wall\n\nHere's where things fall apart. Three layers of falling apart, each one\nmore fundamental than the last.\n\n### Layer 1: The Qwen Disaster\n\nWe started with Qwen2.5-Coder-0.5B. Small, coding-specialized, open-source.\nThe plan: LoRA fine-tuning with our 11,000 conversation turns, 2 epochs,\n4 GPUs, 8,192 token context.\n\nThe loss converged beautifully. Textbook training curve. We were excited.\n\nThen we ran inference.\n\n```\n\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\n\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\n\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\n\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\u003C|fim_middle|>\n...forever\n```\n\nThe model had learned to output a single special token in an infinite loop.\nNot code. Not function calls. Not even coherent text. Just `\u003C|fim_middle|>`\nuntil we killed the process.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/data_pipeline.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 2054: Data Pipeline\"\n  caption=\"11,000 carefully processed conversation turns in, infinite special tokens out.\"\n/>\n\nWhat happened? Three compounding bugs, all documented, none of which\nwe found in time:\n\n**Bug 1: The pad token was the EOS token.** Qwen2.5 ships with `pad_token`\nset to `\u003C|endoftext|>`, which is also the EOS token. During training,\nthe model sees the termination signal as padding throughout every batch.\nIt learns to ignore it. Result: the model never stops generating.\n\n**Bug 2: Untrained special token embeddings.** The special tokens\n`\u003C|im_start|>`, `\u003C|im_end|>`, and others in Qwen2.5-Coder-0.5B have\nessentially *identical* embedding vectors. PCA analysis shows they\ncluster together indistinguishably. The `lm_head` weights for all\nspecial tokens except `\u003C|endoftext|>` are identical, so the model\nliterally cannot tell them apart during generation.\n\n**Bug 3: LoRA freezes the wrong layers.** Standard LoRA freezes\n`embed_tokens` and `lm_head`. With untrained special tokens, those\nare exactly the layers that *need* to be trained. Without including\nthem in `modules_to_save`, the model has no mechanism to learn\nstructured output formats.\n\n\u003CCallout type=\"note\">\nThe Unsloth team documented the pad_token bug in November 2024, four\nmonths before our attempt. They published fixed model weights on\nHuggingFace. We didn't find it. That's on us.\n\u003C/Callout>\n\n### Layer 2: The Mistral Pivot\n\nWe switched to Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3. Bigger model, and critically,\nMistral's v3-tekken tokenizer explicitly supports tool-calling with\ndedicated control tokens: `[TOOL_CALLS]`, `[AVAILABLE_TOOLS]`, etc.\n\nI built a custom preprocessing pipeline from scratch. Parsed every\nconversation turn into structured Python objects. Tokenized them using\n`mistral_common` (Mistral's own tokenization library, not HuggingFace's).\nValidated the output carefully.\n\nThe tokenized data looked perfect. Tool calls and arguments preserved\nintact. Special tokens correctly delineating conversation turns.\n\nThen we plugged it into the HuggingFace training pipeline.\n\nThe problem: HuggingFace's `apply_chat_template` for Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3\nis *not the same* as `mistral_common`. Mistral's own team acknowledged this\non HuggingFace: the tokenizer configuration is \"a bit tricky\" because they\nhave a custom implementation. The HF template, at the time, didn't support\n`tool_use` roles at all. Messages with function-calling content were\neither silently dropped or incorrectly tokenized.\n\nWe had validated our data with the right tokenizer and trained with\nthe wrong one.\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The Tokenizer Mismatch\">\n{`\n  Our preprocessing        HF training pipeline\n  (mistral_common)         (apply_chat_template)\n  ─────────────────        ─────────────────────\n  [AVAILABLE_TOOLS]        (silently dropped)\n  [tool definitions]       (silently dropped)\n  [/AVAILABLE_TOOLS]       (silently dropped)\n  [INST] user msg [/INST]  [INST] user msg [/INST]\n  assistant response       assistant response\n  [TOOL_CALLS]             (silently dropped)\n  {function call json}     (silently dropped)\n  [/TOOL_CALLS]            (silently dropped)\n\n  ✓ validated perfectly    ✗ trained on gutted data\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe model trained successfully. It just never learned function calling,\nbecause the function-calling data wasn't in the training set anymore.\n\n### Layer 3: The Deeper Problem\n\nSuppose both tokenizers had worked perfectly. Suppose the pad token was\nfixed and the embeddings were trained. Would it have worked?\n\nAlmost certainly not.\n\nWe also built a simplified test repository with 10 curated problems ranging\nfrom syntax errors to multi-file logic bugs. A controlled environment\nto isolate what the models could actually do.\n\n\u003CDataTable caption=\"Test Repository Results\">\n\n| Model | Type | Problems Solved (of 10) |\n|-------|------|:-----------------------:|\n| **Mistral-large-latest** | API | **10** |\n| Qwen2.5-Coder-0.5B | Local | 0 |\n| Qwen2.5-Coder-7B | Local | 0 |\n| DeepSeek-Coder variants | Local | 0 |\n| Bitagent-8b | Local | 0 |\n| xLAM-2-fc-r-1b | Local | 0 |\n\n\u003C/DataTable>\n\nEvery locally deployed model, regardless of size, specialization, or\nclaimed function-calling support, solved zero problems. Not on SWE-bench.\nOn our *simplified* test set.\n\nThe failure modes were consistent:\n\n- **Repetitive behavior:** Models would attempt the same solution\n  in a loop despite error messages telling them it didn't work\n- **Context forgetting:** When we applied repetition penalties to\n  break the loops, models lost track of what they'd already tried\n- **Tool misuse:** Models would attempt to access files that don't\n  exist, produce syntactically broken function calls, or use tools\n  in nonsensical sequences\n\nThe problem wasn't just tokenization. It was capacity. A 0.5B model\nhas roughly 1/64th the parameters of the smallest model that's been\nshown to work for SWE-agent tasks (32B). It's like trying to teach\nsomeone to play chess, navigate a city, and speak a foreign language\nsimultaneously, except the student has a 10-word vocabulary.\n\n## The Vindication\n\nHere's the part that stings in the best possible way.\n\nWithin weeks of our March 2025 attempt, multiple top research labs\npublished results doing *exactly what we tried*. Same idea, same\ndata source (Claude traces), same SWE-agent framework.\n\nThe difference: they used 32B+ parameter models.\n\n\u003CDataTable caption=\"The Field Catches Up (March to July 2025)\">\n\n| Project | Team | Base Model | SWE-bench Verified | Date |\n|---------|------|-----------|:------------------:|------|\n| SWE-agent-LM-32B | Princeton | Qwen2.5-Coder-32B | 40.2% | Apr 2025 |\n| DeepSWE | Together AI | Qwen3-32B | 42.2% | Mid 2025 |\n| Devstral | Mistral + OpenHands | 24B specialized | 46.8% | May 2025 |\n| SWE-RL | Meta | Llama-3.3-70B | 41.0% | Feb 2025 |\n| Qwen3-Coder | Alibaba | 480B MoE (35B active) | ~69.6% | Jul 2025 |\n\n\u003C/DataTable>\n\nSWE-smith (Princeton) collected 5,000 successful trajectories from\nSWE-agent + Claude 3.7 Sonnet. Our exact data source, our exact\nframework. They fine-tuned Qwen2.5-Coder-32B to 40.2%. Our 747\ntrajectories are in the same ballpark as SWE-Gym's 491 that produced\nmeaningful results.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/wisdom_of_the_ancients.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 979: Wisdom of the Ancients\"\n  caption=\"Except in this version, someone actually solved it. With a 32B model and a proper tokenizer.\"\n/>\n\nBut the most vindicating finding was about *format*. The SWE-smith\nteam built mini-SWE-agent specifically for fine-tuning, and the key\ndesign decision was to **abandon function-calling entirely**. No structured\nJSON tool calls. No multi-role conversation protocols. Just plain\nbash commands and their output, as simple text continuation.\n\nThe format we spent weeks wrestling with? Structured function calls\nwith special tokens, tool definitions in system prompts, role-based\nmessage parsing. The field concluded it was the wrong abstraction\nfor fine-tuning altogether. The tokenization headaches weren't\nincidental. They were a signal. The format itself was too complex\nfor smaller models to learn reliably.\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"What We Used vs. What Works\">\n{`\n  Our format (function-calling):      What SWE-smith uses (bash):\n\n  {\"role\": \"system\",                  SYSTEM: You solve GitHub\n   \"tools\": [{                        issues. Use bash commands.\n     \"name\": \"edit_file\",\n     \"parameters\": {...}              USER: Fix issue #1234\n   }]}\n  {\"role\": \"assistant\",               ASSISTANT: Let me look at\n   \"function_call\": {                 the relevant file.\n     \"name\": \"edit_file\",             $ cat src/utils.py\n     \"arguments\": \"{...}\"\n   }}                                 SYSTEM: [file contents]\n  {\"role\": \"function\",\n   \"name\": \"edit_file\",               ASSISTANT: I see the bug.\n   \"content\": \"...\"}                  $ edit src/utils.py ...\n\n  complex structured format           plain text continuation\n  special tokens required             any tokenizer works\n  role-based message parsing          linear conversation\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe difference looks cosmetic. It's not. The bash format eliminates\nevery tokenization problem we hit. No special tokens to train. No\nrole-switching protocol. No JSON structure to generate correctly. The\nmodel just learns to write bash commands and read their output, a\npattern that's already in its pretraining data.\n\n## Reflections\n\n### What We Got Wrong\n\n**The model size was a mistake.** This is the hardest thing to admit\nbecause it wasn't a knowledge gap. It was a resource constraint\nthat we rationalized into a research decision. We picked Qwen2.5-Coder-0.5B\nbecause it fit on our hardware, then convinced ourselves it was an\ninteresting experiment to see if a small model could learn agentic behavior.\nThe published literature, even at the time, suggested 7B was a\nfloor for meaningful results on coding tasks, and SWE-bench needed 32B.\n\n**The tokenizer bugs were findable.** The Unsloth documentation existed.\nThe Mistral HuggingFace discussion existed. We didn't search hard enough\nbefore committing to multi-week training runs. In ML, debugging the\npipeline is the work, not an obstacle to it.\n\n**The format was wrong.** We inherited SWE-agent's function-calling\ninterface without questioning whether it was the right abstraction\nfor fine-tuning. It wasn't. The field spent the next few months\nproving that bash-only scaffolds work better for exactly the reasons\nwe discovered: tokenization compatibility, structural simplicity,\nand reduced output complexity for smaller models.\n\n### What We Got Right\n\n**The data pipeline works.** 2,276 logs to 747 solutions to 11,000\nstructured conversation turns, with deduplication, chunking, and\nvalidation. That pipeline mirrors what SWE-smith and SWE-Gym built\nindependently. The [dataset](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1V3uEkmLSQ9K4iPg7NJNjUgFjqc9CyI50?usp=sharing)\nis public and ready to use, not just a homework assignment.\n\n**The diagnosis was correct.** Our paper identified function calling\nas the critical bottleneck, distinct from raw code generation ability.\nDevstral, SWE-smith, and mini-SWE-agent all confirmed this within\nmonths. We couldn't fix it, but we pointed at the right wall.\n\n**The failure modes map cleanly to the literature.** Repetitive behavior,\ncontext forgetting, tool misuse. These are exactly what SWE-Gym,\nSWE-smith, and R2E-Gym documented in models below 32B. We weren't\nobserving random noise. We were observing the capacity boundary.\n\n### What I'd Do Now\n\nWith the benefit of hindsight and the research that followed:\n\nStart with **Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct** (not the base model; the\ninstruct variant has trained special token embeddings). Use the Unsloth\npad_token fix. Include `embed_tokens` and `lm_head` in LoRA's\n`modules_to_save`. Convert the 747 trajectories to **mini-SWE-agent's\nbash-only format**, a data processing task. Exactly what this\nproject proved I can do. For inference, a quantized 32B model fits in\n~20GB of VRAM.\n\nThe 747 traces are still valuable. SWE-Gym got meaningful results from\n491 trajectories at 32B. The data isn't the problem. The data was\nnever the problem.\n\n### The Broader Lesson\n\nThere's a difference between *teaching a model to write code* and\n*teaching a model to be a software engineer*. Code generation is\npattern completion. Software engineering is navigation, diagnosis,\nverification, and iteration. An agentic loop that requires the model\nto maintain state across dozens of interactions while using tools\nit barely understands.\n\nKnowledge distillation works for both. But the second one needs more\nparameters, simpler formats, and the humility to check whether your\ntokenizer is eating your data before you start a training run.\n\nWe had 747 correct answers. The model couldn't learn from any of them.\nThat's not a failure of the data. It's a lesson about what it takes\nto teach a machine to think in loops.","src/content/projects/swe-bench.mdx","0247bbeae91a9ab5","swe-bench.mdx","walk-my-block",{"id":75,"data":77,"body":99,"filePath":100,"digest":101,"legacyId":102,"deferredRender":22},{"title":78,"description":79,"tags":80,"publishedAt":84,"featured":22,"order":56,"tabs":85},"Walk My Block","Walking audio tour with watercolor map overlay. Share audio logs tagged to locations that others discover by visiting.",[81,82,83],"web","maps","community",["Date","2024-10-05T00:00:00.000Z"],[86,89,92,95,98],{"label":87,"id":88},"./overview","overview",{"label":90,"id":91},"./concept","the-concept",{"label":93,"id":94},"./tech","technical-implementation",{"label":96,"id":97},"./hackathon","the-hackathon",{"label":39,"id":40},"## Overview\n\nWalk My Block creates a living museum of your city. Users share audio logs\nor polaroids tagged to their current location—content that only others\ncan discover by physically stumbling onto that spot.\n\n## The Concept\n\nImagine walking down a quiet street and your phone buzzes. Someone recorded\na memory here three months ago. You listen. A stranger's voice tells you\nabout the coffee shop that used to be on this corner, or the time they\nproposed right where you're standing.\n\n## Technical Implementation\n\nBuilt as a web application with Stadia Maps, featuring:\n\n- Beautiful watercolor map overlay aesthetic\n- Location-tagged audio recording and playback\n- Polaroid-style photo uploads\n- Proximity-based content discovery\n- Offline-first architecture for spotty coverage areas\n\n## The Hackathon\n\nPrototyped for Hacks-for-Humanity hackathon, where it was selected as an\norg favourite. The judges loved the emphasis on human connection and\nthe way it encourages people to explore their neighborhoods.\n\n## Reflections\n\n### What Made It Special\n- The serendipity of discovery\n- Low-friction content creation\n- The watercolor aesthetic softened the digital experience\n\n### Future Possibilities\n- Curated walking tours by local historians\n- Integration with city archives\n- Ambient soundscapes for areas without user content","src/content/projects/walk-my-block.mdx","45d6dde8ecf6f22c","walk-my-block.mdx","xv6-kernel",{"id":103,"data":105,"body":120,"filePath":121,"digest":122,"legacyId":123,"deferredRender":22},{"title":106,"description":107,"tags":108,"publishedAt":112,"featured":22,"order":113,"tabs":114},"XV6 OS Kernel Modules","Implemented multithreading, on-demand paging, bootloading, and trap-and-emulate virtualization in xv6.",[109,110,111],"c","os","systems",["Date","2024-09-15T00:00:00.000Z"],5,[115,116,119],{"label":87,"id":88},{"label":117,"id":118},"./features","implemented-features",{"label":39,"id":40},"## Overview\n\nExtended the xv6 educational operating system with production-grade features,\ndiving deep into how operating systems actually work under the hood.\n\n## Implemented Features\n\n### Multithreading\n\nAdded POSIX-style threading support to xv6:\n\n```c\nint thread_create(void (*fn)(void*), void *arg) {\n    struct proc *np;\n    struct proc *curproc = myproc();\n    \n    // Allocate process\n    if ((np = allocproc()) == 0)\n        return -1;\n    \n    // Share address space with parent\n    np->pgdir = curproc->pgdir;\n    np->sz = curproc->sz;\n    \n    // Set up stack and entry point\n    // ...\n}\n```\n\n### On-Demand Paging\n\nImplemented lazy page allocation—pages are only allocated when actually\naccessed, not when requested:\n\n- Page fault handler for missing pages\n- Copy-on-write for fork optimization\n- Swap space management\n\n### Bootloading\n\nWrote a custom bootloader that:\n- Loads kernel from disk\n- Sets up protected mode\n- Initializes page tables\n- Jumps to kernel entry point\n\n### Trap and Emulate Virtualization\n\nImplemented basic virtualization support allowing xv6 to host guest\noperating systems through trap-and-emulate:\n\n- Sensitive instruction trapping\n- Virtual memory management for guests\n- Device emulation layer\n\n## Reflections\n\n### What I Learned\n- The elegance of Unix's design decisions\n- How much complexity modern OSes hide from us\n- Why debugging kernel code requires patience\n\n### Challenges\n- Race conditions in the scheduler\n- Getting page table math right\n- The bootloader's 512-byte limit\n\nThis project gave me deep appreciation for systems programming and the\nlayers of abstraction we build on every day.","src/content/projects/xv6-kernel.mdx","95fe0c850fd6bd78","xv6-kernel.mdx","autocss",{"id":124,"data":126,"body":149,"filePath":150,"digest":151,"legacyId":152,"deferredRender":22},{"title":127,"description":128,"tags":129,"publishedAt":133,"featured":22,"github":134,"order":135,"tabs":136},"AutoCSS: A Hackathon Retrospective","In 2017, I built a tool to convert hand-drawn wireframes to HTML using OpenCV contour detection. Seven years later, VLMs do this with a single API call. A love letter to scrappy engineering.",[51,130,131,132],"opencv","hackathon","retrospective",["Date","2026-02-05T00:00:00.000Z"],"https://github.com/ethereal-keys/AutoCSS",2,[137,140,143,146],{"label":138,"id":139},"./the-pitch","the-pitch",{"label":141,"id":142},"./how-it-works","how-it-works",{"label":144,"id":145},"./the-twist","the-twist",{"label":147,"id":148},"./coda","coda","## The Pitch\n\nIn 2017, at a hackathon somewhere in my early undergrad, I had what felt like a\nbrilliant idea: what if you could sketch a website layout on paper, point a\ncamera at it, and have working HTML pop out the other end?\n\n\u003CComic \n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/tasks.png\" \n  alt=\"XKCD 1425: Tasks\" \n  caption=\"'In the 60s, Marvin Minsky assigned a couple of undergrads to spend the summer programming a computer to use a camera to identify objects in a scene. He figured they'd have the problem solved by the end of the summer. Half a century later, we're still working on it.'\"\n/>\n\nThe comic's punchline is that identifying whether a photo contains a bird \nrequires a research team and five years. Converting hand-drawn wireframes \nto code? That was _our_ bird.\n\nBut we were undergrads with 48 hours, a laptop, and the unwavering confidence\nthat comes from not knowing what you don't know.\n\nSo we built it anyway.\n\n## How It Works\n\nHere's what we were trying to do:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The Dream\">\n{`\n    ┌─────────────┐         ┌─────────────┐\n    │  ┌───────┐  │         │   \u003Cdiv>     │\n    │  │ ███   │  │         │     \u003Cdiv>   │\n    │  ├───┬───┤  │   ───▶  │       ...   │\n    │  │ █ │ █ │  │         │     \u003C/div>  │\n    │  └───┴───┘  │         │   \u003C/div>    │\n    └─────────────┘         └─────────────┘\n      hand-drawn               HTML output\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe key insight: **OpenCV already knows how to find nested shapes.** We just\nhad to convince it that rectangles-inside-rectangles is the same thing as\ndivs-inside-divs.\n\n### The Pipeline\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"Processing Pipeline\">\n{`\n  ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐\n  │  Input   │    │ Cleanup  │    │  Edges   │    │ Contours │    │  Output  │\n  │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │\n  │  photo   │───▶│threshold │───▶│  canny   │───▶│RETR_TREE │───▶│   HTML   │\n  │  of      │    │  + blur  │    │  edge    │    │ hierarchy│    │   DOM    │\n  │ drawing  │    │          │    │detection │    │          │    │   tree   │\n  └──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nAnd here's what that actually looked like:\n\n\u003CAnimatedImage \n  src=\"/images/autocss/autocss-pipeline.gif\"\n  staticSrc=\"/images/autocss/autocss-pipeline-static.jpg\"\n  alt=\"AutoCSS processing pipeline animation\"\n  caption=\"Click to play: from paper sketch to detected contours in 5 steps\"\n/>\n\nEach frame shows a real intermediate output from the pipeline:\n\n1. **Input**: The hand-drawn wireframe on paper\n2. **Binarized**: Threshold to clean black-on-white\n3. **Edges**: Canny edge detection finds the lines\n4. **Contours**: OpenCV traces every closed shape (notice the double lines!)\n5. **Output**: Clean bounding rectangles, ready for DOM conversion\n\nThe magic happens in step 4. Let me show you.\n\n### The RETR_TREE Trick\n\nWhen you call `cv2.findContours()`, you can choose how to organize the results.\nMost tutorials use `RETR_EXTERNAL` (just outer shapes) or `RETR_LIST` (flat list).\n\nWe used `RETR_TREE`.\n\nThis returns the full parent-child hierarchy of every contour. And here's the\nthing: **a contour hierarchy is already a DOM tree.**\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"Contour Hierarchy = DOM Tree\">\n{`\n  What OpenCV returns:              What HTML needs:\n\n  Contour 0 (outermost)            \u003Cdiv>          ← root\n    ├── Contour 1                    \u003Cdiv>        ← child\n    │     ├── Contour 3                \u003Cdiv/>     ← grandchild\n    │     └── Contour 4                \u003Cdiv/>     ← grandchild\n    └── Contour 2                    \u003Cdiv/>       ← child\n                                   \u003C/div>\n\n  Same structure.                  Same structure.\n  Different syntax.\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe recursive function to walk this tree is tiny:\n\n```python\ndef build_dom(contour_idx, hierarchy):\n    \"\"\"Walk contour tree, emit nested divs.\"\"\"\n    node = hierarchy[0][contour_idx]\n    child_idx = node[2]  # First child\n    \n    if child_idx == -1:\n        return \"\u003Cp>content\u003C/p>\"  # Leaf node\n    \n    html = \"\"\n    while child_idx != -1:\n        html += f\"\u003Cdiv>{build_dom(child_idx, hierarchy)}\u003C/div>\"\n        child_idx = hierarchy[0][child_idx][0]  # Next sibling\n    \n    return html\n```\n\nThat's it. That's the whole DOM generation. Ten lines.\n\n\u003CComic \n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/machine_learning.png\" \n  alt=\"XKCD 1838: Machine Learning\" \n  caption=\"People kept asking if we used machine learning. We didn't even have a pile.\"\n/>\n\n### The Double Contour Problem\n\nOf course, nothing is that simple. Hand-drawn lines aren't perfect geometric\nshapes. Edge detection on thick marker strokes produces... interesting results.\n\nWhen Canny runs on a hand-drawn line, it finds *two* edges, one on each side\nof the ink stroke. This means every rectangle becomes two nested contours:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The Double Contour Problem\">\n{`\n  What you draw:          What OpenCV sees:\n\n      ████████                ┌──────────┐  ← outer edge of ink\n      █      █                │ ┌──────┐ │  ← inner edge of ink\n      █      █       ───▶     │ │      │ │\n      █      █                │ │      │ │\n      ████████                │ └──────┘ │\n                              └──────────┘\n\n   One rectangle            Two nested contours!\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nWithout fixing this, every `\u003Cdiv>` would have a useless wrapper div inside it.\n\n### The Fix: Skip Single Children\n\nThe solution is elegant: if a contour has exactly one child, and that child\nis roughly the same size, skip the parent and promote the grandchildren:\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The dup_tree Fix\">\n{`\n  Before:                        After:\n\n       ┌───┐                         ┌───┐\n       │ 0 │                         │ 0 │\n       └─┬─┘                         └─┬─┘\n         │                             │\n       ┌─┴─┐ ← single child,      ┌───┴────┐\n       │ 1 │   same size          │        │\n       └─┬─┘   (duplicate!)     ┌─┴─┐   ┌─┴─┐\n         │                      │ 2 │   │ 3 │\n     ┌───┴────┐                 └───┘   └───┘\n     │        │\n   ┌─┴─┐   ┌─┴─┐               Grandchildren promoted!\n   │ 2 │   │ 3 │\n   └───┘   └───┘\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe `dup_tree()` function walks the tree bottom-up, pruning these ghost nodes.\nIt's 15 lines of Python and it turned the output from \"unusable mess of\nnested wrappers\" to \"actually correct DOM structure.\"\n\nNested boxes became nested divs. That's not nothing.\n\n## The Twist\n\nTo understand why our approach made sense, you need to understand what the\nworld looked like in 2017.\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"The 2017 AI Landscape\">\n{`\n  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐\n  │                    WHAT WAS HOT IN 2017                         │\n  ├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤\n  │                                                                 │\n  │  GANs ████████████████████████████  CycleGAN, pix2pix          │\n  │  CNNs ███████████████████████       \"ImageNet is solved\"        │\n  │  RNNs ██████████████                Seq2seq, attention          │\n  │  RL   █████████                     AlphaGo hype                │\n  │                                                                 │\n  │  Transformers █                     (just published, ignored)   │\n  │                                                                 │\n  └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nThe transformer paper, \"Attention Is All You Need,\" was published **June 12, 2017**.\nThe same summer we were probably building this. Nobody knew what it would become.\n\nAt a hackathon in 2017, you used **OpenCV**:\n- Ran on any laptop (no GPU required)\n- Excellent Python bindings\n- Thousands of tutorials\n- Actually worked in 48 hours\n\nDeep learning meant training CNNs for days on a GPU cluster. Not hackathon-friendly.\n\n### What Others Were Building\n\nWe weren't alone in trying sketch-to-code:\n\n\u003CDataTable caption=\"Other Sketch-to-Code Projects\">\n| Project | Approach | Result |\n|---------|----------|--------|\n| **Pix2Code** (2017) | CNN + LSTM | 77% accuracy on 16 synthetic tokens |\n| **Airbnb** (2017) | Component classifier | Only worked with their 150 pre-defined components |\n| **Microsoft Sketch2Code** (2018) | Azure CV + rules | Supported 5 element types |\n\u003C/DataTable>\n\nEveryone had the same idea. Nobody cracked it.\n\n\u003CComic \n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/automation.png\" \n  alt=\"XKCD 1319: Automation\" \n  caption=\"We spent 48 hours automating something that takes 30 minutes by hand.\"\n/>\n\n### Then, March 2023\n\nThe GPT-4 Developer Livestream. Greg Brockman photographs a hand-drawn\nsketch on a napkin. Seconds later: a working website.\n\n\u003CYouTubeEmbed videoId=\"outcGtbnMuQ\" title=\"GPT-4 Developer Livestream\" start={982} />\n\nThe exact project we built in 2017. But working perfectly, instantly, with no\nedge detection, no RETR_TREE, no \"draw with thick marker in good lighting.\"\n\n### The Difference\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"2017 vs 2024\">\n{`\n  AutoCSS (2017):                    GPT-4V (2024):\n\n  ┌──────────┐                       ┌──────────┐\n  │ pixels   │                       │ pixels   │\n  └────┬─────┘                       └────┬─────┘\n       │                                  │\n       ▼                                  │\n  ┌──────────┐                            │\n  │ edges    │                            │\n  └────┬─────┘                            │\n       │                                  │\n       ▼                                  ▼\n  ┌──────────┐                       ┌──────────┐\n  │ contours │                       │\"I see a  │\n  └────┬─────┘                       │ search   │\n       │                             │ bar and  │\n       ▼                             │ a nav    │\n  ┌──────────┐                       │ menu...\" │\n  │hierarchy │                       └────┬─────┘\n  └────┬─────┘                            │\n       │                                  ▼\n       ▼                             ┌──────────┐\n  ┌──────────┐                       │ working  │\n  │nested    │                       │ React +  │\n  │divs      │                       │ Tailwind │\n  └──────────┘                       └──────────┘\n\n  Geometry                           Understanding\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>\n\nWhere we saw \"rectangle at (100,200) with width 300,\" a VLM sees \"search bar\nin header, probably e-commerce, needs placeholder text.\"\n\nThe Stanford Design2Code benchmark (2024): GPT-4V generated pages that could\n**replace originals 49% of the time** on 484 real websites.\n\nNot 77% on 16 synthetic tokens. Near-majority replacement on arbitrary sites.\n\n### The Modern Toolkit\n\n- **tldraw Make Real**: Draw → HTML/Tailwind. ~$0.04 per generation.\n- **screenshot-to-code**: 71K+ GitHub stars. Any mockup → React/Vue/HTML.\n- **v0.dev**: 6M+ developers. Production components from sketches.\n\nOne API call. No contour detection required.\n\n## Coda\n\n\u003CComic \n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/wanna_see_the_code.png\" \n  alt=\"XKCD 2138: Wanna See the Code?\" \n  caption=\"Opening the repo after 7 years felt exactly like this.\"\n/>\n\nI recently opened the AutoCSS repository for the first time in seven years.\n\nThe code is exactly what you'd expect:\n- Jupyter notebooks as the main codebase\n- Variables named `heirarchy` (typo preserved for posterity)\n- Commented-out print statements everywhere\n- Hardcoded paths to `lay6.png`\n\nIt's a mess. It's also a time capsule.\n\n### What Hackathons Are For\n\nHackathons aren't about production code. They're about asking \"what if?\"\n\nWhat if contour hierarchies mapped to DOM trees? They do.\nWhat if you could draw a website and have it appear? You can.\nWhat if the weird idea could work? Sometimes.\n\n### The Right Idea, Wrong Time\n\nThe core insight (visual layouts should convert directly to code) was right.\nThe industry spent seven years proving it.\n\nWe were just too early, with tools too primitive.\n\nThere's something satisfying about that. Building something that anticipated\nwhere the field was going, even if we couldn't get there ourselves.\n\n### The Code Is Still There\n\nThe repository is public. The contours still detect on clean drawings.\n\nIt's not useful anymore. But it's mine.\n\nAnd somewhere in those nested loops and misspelled variables is proof that\nI once spent 48 hours turning hand-drawn boxes into HTML because I thought\nit would be cool.\n\nIt was.","src/content/projects/autocss.mdx","3bf32f1511ab6ccd","autocss.mdx","posts",["Map",155,156],"on-drawing",{"id":155,"data":157,"body":166,"filePath":167,"digest":168,"legacyId":169,"deferredRender":22},{"title":158,"description":159,"tags":160,"publishedAt":163,"related":164,"draft":165},"Drawing by Hand in the Age of Midjourney","On gesture drawings, creative bursts, and why generating an image isn't the same as making one.",[161,162,20],"art","personal",["Date","2026-02-12T00:00:00.000Z"],[],false,"A few curves is all it takes.\n\nA C-shape for the torso, a longer sweep for the leg bearing weight,\na quick flick for the one that isn't. Two minutes, maybe less. The\nfigure on your page doesn't look like the person in front of you.\nIt looks like the *feeling* of the person in front of you. The\nweight, the lean, the tension in the shoulders.\n\nThat's what hooked me.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"/images/writing/ink-and-patience/gesture-reference.jpeg\"\n  alt=\"Gesture study next to reference photo\"\n  caption=\"Decomposing a pose into curves and weight. The photo is precise. The sketch is alive.\"\n  width=\"70%\"\n/>\n\nI didn't start drawing seriously until college. Before that it was\ndoodling in notebook margins, the kind of thing you do when your\nhands need something to do and your brain needs somewhere quieter.\nIn college, that need got louder. Crowded rooms, long lectures,\nthe kind of days where my focus would scatter if my hands stayed\nstill.\n\nSo I drew. Not well. Not with purpose. Just lines on paper until\nthe noise quieted down.\n\nSomewhere in there, gesture drawing found me. The idea that a\nhuman body, in all its complexity, could be captured in a few\nconfident strokes. That a still image could look like it was\nabout to move. That's the feeling I chase every time I pick up\na pen. Not accuracy. *Movement.*\n\n## The Burst Problem\n\nHere's the thing nobody tells you about creative practice: wanting\nit badly doesn't make it happen consistently.\n\nI go weeks without touching a sketchbook. Then something shifts.\nSome restlessness builds up, or I see a face that I need to put\non paper, or I just can't sit still anymore. And then I draw for\nhours.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"/images/writing/ink-and-patience/rain-portrait.jpeg\"\n  alt=\"Ink portrait of a man in rain, taped to a board\"\n  caption=\"One of those bursts. Black pen, cheap paper, taped to a board afterward because I liked how it turned out.\"\n  width=\"70%\"\n/>\n\nThe bursts produce my best work. The portraits with real weight\nbehind them, the ones where the linework feels alive. But bursts\naren't discipline. And craft requires discipline.\n\nI know the gap between where I am and where I want to be is\nmade of all the days I didn't draw. That's my oldest creative\nfrustration. I suspect it's a common one.\n\n## What Ink Teaches You\n\nThere's a thing that happens when you draw with ink. You can't\nundo.\n\nPencil lets you hedge. Digital lets you ctrl+z. Ink is permanent\nthe moment it touches paper. You commit to a line before you know\nif it's right. And when it's wrong (and it will be wrong), you\ndon't erase it. You work with it. You let the mistake become part\nof the drawing, or you push the next line harder to compensate.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"/images/writing/ink-and-patience/girl-glasses.jpeg\"\n  alt=\"Brush pen portrait of a girl with glasses\"\n  caption=\"Brush pen. The cape is one continuous motion. You can see where the pen hesitated and where it didn't.\"\n  width=\"70%\"\n/>\n\nI won't pretend this makes you a better software engineer. But\nthe patience it requires, sitting with something that isn't\nworking and resisting the urge to start over, finding the next\nright line instead of mourning the last wrong one, that patience\nis transferable. Not as a skill. As a temperament.\n\n\u003CCallout type=\"note\">\nDrawing is a reminder that some things can only be *practiced*.\nThere's no architecture to refactor, no algorithm to improve.\nJust your hand, your eye, and the gap between what you see and\nwhat you can put on paper. That gap never fully closes. You just\nget more comfortable living inside it.\n\u003C/Callout>\n\n## The Process Is the Point\n\nI work in machine learning. I built a neural style transfer\nplugin that teaches a network to paint like Van Gogh in real-time.\nI've spent more hours than I'd like to admit training models on\nartistic data. So I don't say any of this from the outside.\n\nAI image generation is impressive. The outputs are often\nbeautiful. That's not the interesting question.\n\nThe interesting question is: what do you lose if the only images\nyou ever make are the ones you type a sentence to produce?\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/is_it_worth_the_time.png\"\n  alt=\"XKCD 1205: Is It Worth the Time?\"\n  caption=\"This chart doesn't have a column for 'things worth doing even if they're not efficient.'\"\n/>\n\nYou lose the hours of bad gesture drawings that eventually\nproduce one good one. The specific frustration of getting a\njawline wrong three times before the fourth attempt lands.\nThe evening spent on a ruffled collar that you almost gave\nup on twice before the whole composition clicked.\n\n\u003CComic\n  src=\"/images/writing/ink-and-patience/ram-horned-woman.jpeg\"\n  alt=\"Detailed ink drawing of a woman with ram horns and ruffled collar\"\n  caption=\"That collar took longer than the rest of the drawing combined.\"\n  width=\"70%\"\n/>\n\nWhen I look at this drawing, I don't just see the image. I\nremember making it. The way the horns came together before\nthe face did. The moment I almost scrapped the collar and the\nmoment it started working. That story is part of what the\ndrawing *is*. It exists because I sat with it for hours, not\nbecause I described it in a sentence.\n\nEven watching someone else draw has this quality. Seeing a\nperson who has mastered a craft, or who is visibly in the\nmiddle of mastering it, the hand moving with intention, the\nmistakes left in. There's something there that no output,\nhowever polished, can carry on its own.\n\nThe efficiency argument misses the point entirely. Of course\na prompt is faster than a pen.\n\nArt is more than the artifact. It's the making of it. And\nthe making is something you have to do with your hands.\n\n## The Pen Is Still Here\n\nMy sketchbook is on my desk right now. The brush pen is next\nto it. I haven't opened it in eleven days. I know this because\nI checked before writing this sentence.\n\nTomorrow it might be twelve. Or tomorrow I might draw for three\nhours and fill four pages and feel like myself again.\n\nThat's how it works. The practice isn't daily. The desire is.\nAnd I think that's enough to keep going, even if it doesn't\nlook like discipline from the outside.\n\nIf you're an engineer who used to draw, or who always wanted\nto, or who doodles in meetings and feels vaguely guilty about\nit: the pen is still there. Pick it up. Draw badly. Draw the\nsame face six times until the seventh one has something in it\nyou can't explain.\n\nIt won't make you a better programmer. It'll make you a more\npatient person. And those are sometimes the same thing.\n\n\u003CAsciiDiagram title=\"\">\n{`\n   /\\\\_/\\\\\n  ( ^.^ )\n`}\n\u003C/AsciiDiagram>","src/content/posts/on-drawing.mdx","b49571abbba2ed96","on-drawing.mdx"]
