class="_tabContent_1176a_65" role="tabpanel"><astro-slot> <div class="prose" data-astro-cid-ovxcmftc> <h2 id="the-pitch">The Pitch</h2>
<p>In 2017, at a hackathon somewhere in my early undergrad, I had what felt like a
brilliant idea: what if you could sketch a website layout on paper, point a
camera at it, and have working HTML pop out the other end?</p>
<figure class="comic align-center" style data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <div class="comic-frame" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┘</span> <img src="https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/tasks.png" alt="XKCD 1425: Tasks" class="comic-image" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> </div> <figcaption class="comic-caption" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>&#39;In the 60s, Marvin Minsky assigned a couple of undergrads to spend the summer programming a computer to use a camera to identify objects in a scene. He figured they&#39;d have the problem solved by the end of the summer. Half a century later, we&#39;re still working on it.&#39;</span> </figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The comic’s punchline is that identifying whether a photo contains a bird
requires a research team and five years. Converting hand-drawn wireframes
to code? That’s also a bird.</p>
<p>But we were undergrads with 48 hours, a laptop, and the unwavering confidence
that comes from not knowing what you don’t know.</p>
<p>So we built it anyway.</p>
<h2 id="the-hack">The Hack</h2>
<p>Here’s what we were trying to do:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
  ┌─────────────┐         ┌─────────────┐
  │  ┌───────┐  │         │   &lt;div&gt;     │
  │  │ ███   │  │         │     &lt;div&gt;   │
  │  ├───┬───┤  │   ───▶  │       ...   │
  │  │ █ │ █ │  │         │     &lt;/div&gt;  │
  │  └───┴───┘  │         │   &lt;/div&gt;    │
  └─────────────┘         └─────────────┘
    hand-drawn               HTML output
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>The Dream</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The key insight: <strong>OpenCV already knows how to find nested shapes.</strong> We just
had to convince it that rectangles-inside-rectangles is the same thing as
divs-inside-divs.</p>
<h3 id="the-pipeline">The Pipeline</h3>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐    ┌──────────┐
│  Input   │    │ Cleanup  │    │  Edges   │    │ Contours │    │  Output  │
│ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │    │ ──────── │
│  photo   │───▶│threshold │───▶│  canny   │───▶│RETR_TREE │───▶│   HTML   │
│  of      │    │  + blur  │    │  edge    │    │ hierarchy│    │   DOM    │
│ drawing  │    │          │    │detection │    │          │    │   tree   │
└──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘    └──────────┘
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>Processing Pipeline</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>And here’s what that actually looked like:</p>
<div class="animated-image-wrapper" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <figure class="animated-image" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <div class="image-frame" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>┘</span> <div class="image-container" data-static="/images/autocss/autocss-pipeline-static.jpg" data-animated="/images/autocss/autocss-pipeline.gif" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <img src="/images/autocss/autocss-pipeline-static.jpg" alt="AutoCSS processing pipeline animation" class="display-image" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <button class="play-button" aria-label="Play animation" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <span class="play-icon" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>▶</span> <span class="play-text" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>Play</span> </button> </div> </div> <figcaption class="image-caption" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-2hqv6sh3>Click to play — from paper sketch to detected contours in 5 steps</span> </figcaption> </figure> </div>  
<p>Each frame shows a real intermediate output from the pipeline:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Input</strong> — The hand-drawn wireframe on paper</li>
<li><strong>Binarized</strong> — Threshold to clean black-on-white</li>
<li><strong>Edges</strong> — Canny edge detection finds the lines</li>
<li><strong>Contours</strong> — OpenCV traces every closed shape (notice the double lines!)</li>
<li><strong>Output</strong> — Clean bounding rectangles, ready for DOM conversion</li>
</ol>
<p>The magic happens in step 4. Let me show you.</p>
<h2 id="the-insight">The Insight</h2>
<p>When you call <code>cv2.findContours()</code>, you can choose how to organize the results.
Most tutorials use <code>RETR_EXTERNAL</code> (just outer shapes) or <code>RETR_LIST</code> (flat list).</p>
<p>We used <code>RETR_TREE</code>. And that changed everything.</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
The drawing:                 The hierarchy array:
┌─────────────────────┐
│         0           │      index │ Next  Prev  Child  Parent
│  ┌─────┐  ┌─────┐   │      ──────┼────────────────────────────
│  │  1  │  │  2  │   │        0   │  -1    -1     1      -1    ← root (no parent)
│  │     │  │ ┌─┐ │   │        1   │   2    -1    -1       0    ← child of 0
│  └─────┘  │ │3│ │   │        2   │  -1     1     3       0    ← sibling of 1
│           │ └─┘ │   │        3   │  -1    -1    -1       2    ← child of 2
│           └─────┘   │
└─────────────────────┘      Parent links form a tree!
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>What RETR_TREE Gives You</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>See that <code>Parent</code> column? Contour 1’s parent is 0. Contour 3’s parent is 2.
<strong>The parent-child relationships are already computed for us.</strong></p>
<p>This maps directly to how the DOM works:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
Contour hierarchy:              HTML DOM:

       ┌───┐                    &lt;div&gt;              &lt;!-- contour 0 --&gt;
       │ 0 │                      │
       └─┬─┘                      ├─ &lt;div/&gt;        &lt;!-- contour 1 --&gt;
         │                        │
    ┌────┴────┐                   └─ &lt;div&gt;         &lt;!-- contour 2 --&gt;
  ┌─┴─┐     ┌─┴─┐                      │
  │ 1 │     │ 2 │                      └─ &lt;div/&gt;   &lt;!-- contour 3 --&gt;
  └───┘     └─┬─┘                    
           ┌─┴─┐                 &lt;/div&gt;
           │ 3 │
           └───┘

Same structure. Different syntax.
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>Contours → DOM</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The recursive function to walk this tree is tiny:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> build_dom</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">contour_idx</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> hierarchy</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    &quot;&quot;&quot;Walk contour tree, emit nested divs.&quot;&quot;&quot;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    node </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> hierarchy</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">]</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">[contour_idx]</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    child_idx </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> node</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">2</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">]</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">  # First child</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    if</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> child_idx </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">==</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> -</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">1</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">:</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">        return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)"> &quot;&lt;p&gt;content&lt;/p&gt;&quot;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">  # Leaf node</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    html </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)"> &quot;&quot;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    while</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> child_idx </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">!=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> -</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">1</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">:</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">        html </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">+=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> f</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&quot;&lt;div&gt;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">{</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">build_dom</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(child_idx, hierarchy)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">}</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&lt;/div&gt;&quot;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">        child_idx </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> hierarchy</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">]</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">[child_idx][</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">]  </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)"># Next sibling</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> html</span></span></code></pre>

<figure class="comic align-center" style data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <div class="comic-frame" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┘</span> <img src="https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/machine_learning.png" alt="XKCD 1838: Machine Learning" class="comic-image" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> </div> <figcaption class="comic-caption" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>People kept asking if we used machine learning. We didn&#39;t even have a pile.</span> </figcaption> </figure> 
<h2 id="edge-cases">Edge Cases</h2>
<p>Of course, nothing is that simple. Hand-drawn lines aren’t perfect geometric
shapes. Edge detection on thick marker strokes produces… interesting results.</p>
<h3 id="the-double-contour-problem">The Double Contour Problem</h3>
<p>When Canny runs on a hand-drawn line, it finds <em>two</em> edges—one on each side
of the ink stroke. This means every rectangle becomes two nested contours:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
What you draw:          What OpenCV sees:

    ████████                ┌──────────┐  ← outer edge of ink
    █      █                │ ┌──────┐ │  ← inner edge of ink
    █      █       ───▶     │ │      │ │
    █      █                │ │      │ │
    ████████                │ └──────┘ │
                            └──────────┘

 One rectangle            Two nested contours!
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>The Double Contour Problem</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>Without fixing this, every <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> would have a useless wrapper div inside it.</p>
<h3 id="the-fix-skip-single-children">The Fix: Skip Single Children</h3>
<p>The solution is elegant: if a contour has exactly one child, and that child
is roughly the same size, skip the parent and promote the grandchildren:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
Before:                        After:

     ┌───┐                         ┌───┐
     │ 0 │                         │ 0 │
     └─┬─┘                         └─┬─┘
       │                             │
     ┌─┴─┐ ← single child,      ┌───┴────┐
     │ 1 │   same size          │        │
     └─┬─┘   (duplicate!)     ┌─┴─┐    ┌─┴─┐
       │                      │ 2 │    │ 3 │
  ┌────┴────┐                 └───┘    └───┘
┌─┴─┐     ┌─┴─┐
│ 2 │     │ 3 │               Grandchildren promoted!
└───┘     └───┘
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>The dup_tree Fix</figcaption> </figure> 
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> remove_duplicates</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">tree</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    &quot;&quot;&quot;Skip single-child nodes (they&#39;re contour duplicates).&quot;&quot;&quot;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    if</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> not</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> tree</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">:</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">        return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)"> {}</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    if</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> len</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(tree)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> ==</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> 1</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">:</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">        # Only one child? Skip this level.</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">        only_child </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> list</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(tree.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">values</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">())</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">]</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">        return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> remove_duplicates</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(only_child)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    # Multiple children? Keep this node, recurse into children.</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)"> {</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">k</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">:</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> remove_duplicates</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(v)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> for</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> k</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> v </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">in</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> tree</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">items</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">()}</span></span></code></pre>

<p>What we couldn’t do:</p>

edge detection, no RETR_TREE, no “draw with thick marker in good lighting.”</p>
<h3 id="the-difference">The Difference</h3>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
AutoCSS (2017):                    GPT-4V (2024):

┌──────────┐                       ┌──────────┐
│ pixels   │                       │ pixels   │
└────┬─────┘                       └────┬─────┘
     │                                  │
     ▼                                  │
┌──────────┐                            │
│ edges    │                            │
└────┬─────┘                            │
     │                                  │
     ▼                                  ▼
┌──────────┐                       ┌──────────┐
│ contours │                       │&quot;I see a  │
└────┬─────┘                       │ search   │
     │                             │ bar and  │
     ▼                             │ a nav    │
┌──────────┐                       │ menu...&quot; │
│hierarchy │                       └────┬─────┘
└────┬─────┘                            │
     │                                  ▼
     ▼                             ┌──────────┐
┌──────────┐                       │ working  │
│nested    │                       │ React +  │
│divs      │                       │ Tailwind │
└──────────┘                       └──────────┘

Geometry                           Understanding
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>2017 vs 2024</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>Where we saw “rectangle at (100,200) with width 300,” a VLM sees “search bar
in header, probably e-commerce, needs placeholder text.”</p>
<p>The Stanford Design2Code benchmark (2024): GPT-4V generated pages that could
<strong>replace originals 49% of the time</strong> on 484 real websites.</p>
<p>Not 77% on 16 synthetic tokens. Near-majority replacement on arbitrary sites.</p>
<h3 id="the-modern-toolkit">The Modern Toolkit</h3>
<ul>
<li><strong>tldraw Make Real</strong>: Draw → HTML/Tailwind. ~$0.04 per generation.</li>
<li><strong>screenshot-to-code</strong>: 71K+ GitHub stars. Any mockup → React/Vue/HTML.</li>
<li><strong>v0.dev</strong>: 6M+ developers. Production components from sketches.</li>
</ul>
<p>One API call. No contour detection required.</p>
<h2 id="coda">Coda</h2>
<figure class="comic align-center" style data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <div class="comic-frame" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┘</span> <img src="https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/wanna_see_the_code.png" alt="XKCD 2138: Wanna See the Code?" class="comic-image" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> </div> <figcaption class="comic-caption" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>Opening the repo after 7 years felt exactly like this.</span> </figcaption> </figure> 
<p>I recently opened the AutoCSS repository for the first time in seven years.</p>
<p>The code is exactly what you’d expect:</p>
<ul>
<li>Jupyter notebooks as the main codebase</li>
<li>Variables named <code>heirarchy</code> (typo preserved for posterity)</li>
<li>Commented-out print statements everywhere</li>
<li>Hardcoded paths to <code>lay6.png</code></li>
</ul>
<p>It’s a mess. It’s also a time capsule.</p>
<h3 id="what-hackathons-are-for">What Hackathons Are For</h3>
<p>Hackathons aren’t about production code. They’re about asking “what if?”</p>
<p>What if contour hierarchies mapped to DOM trees? They do.
What if you could draw a website and have it appear? You can.
What if the weird idea could work? Sometimes.</p>
<h3 id="the-right-idea-wrong-time">The Right Idea, Wrong Time</h3>
<p>The core insight—visual layouts should convert directly to code—was right.
The industry spent seven years proving it.</p>
<p>We were just too early, with tools too primitive.</p>
<p>There’s something satisfying about that. Building something that anticipated
where the field was going, even if we couldn’t get there ourselves.</p>
<h3 id="the-code-is-still-there">The Code Is Still There</h3>
<p>The repository is public. The contours still detect on clean drawings.</p>
<p>It’s not useful anymore. But it’s mine.</p>
<p>And somewhere in those nested loops and misspelled variables is proof that
I once spent 48 hours turning hand-drawn boxes into HTML because I thought
it would be cool.</p>
<p>It was.</p> </div> </astro-slot></div></div><!--astro:end--></astro-island> </article> <nav class="project-nav" aria-label="Project navigation" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2> <div class="nav-divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2>

<p>This project started the way many do: I asked ChatGPT for ideas.</p>
<p>The prompt — and I’m quoting my actual history here — went something like:
<em>“give me something that can be implemented in 45 days working 5-8 hrs per week…
something to do with graphics maybe? can you think of problems that can be solved
by a certain hypothesis and needs to be experimented to confirm and get results?”</em></p>
<p>What I got back eventually led me to neural style transfer inside a game engine.
The kind of project where you look at the scope and think “yeah, 45 days, sure.”</p>
<h3 id="the-baseline-45-seconds-per-frame">The Baseline: 45 Seconds Per Frame</h3>
<p>I started where anyone would: the original Gatys et al. paper. The idea is
beautiful — you take a content image and a style image, then iteratively
optimize the pixels until the output looks like the content <em>painted in</em> the style.</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> style_transfer</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">content</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> style</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> iterations</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">500</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    # This took 45 seconds per frame</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    for</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> i </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">in</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> range</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(iterations):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">        optimize_step</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(content, style)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> content</span></span></code></pre>
<p>The results were gorgeous. The performance was not.</p>
<p>45 seconds. Per frame. For a game targeting 60fps, I needed to be roughly
2,700 times faster.</p>
<figure class="comic align-center" style data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <div class="comic-frame" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>┘</span> <img src="https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/compiling.png" alt="XKCD 303: Compiling" class="comic-image" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> </div> <figcaption class="comic-caption" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-5q6s7bto>Me, waiting 45 seconds per frame, telling myself it&#39;s &#39;research time.&#39;</span> </figcaption> </figure> 
<h3 id="the-fix-dont-optimize-at-runtime">The Fix: Don’t Optimize at Runtime</h3>
<p>The breakthrough came from Johnson et al.’s feed-forward approach. Instead of
running 500 optimization steps per frame, you train a neural network <em>once</em> to
perform the style transformation in a single forward pass.</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
Gatys et al. (2016):              Johnson et al. (2016):

┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐
│  Input   │                      │  Input   │
│  Frame   │                      │  Frame   │
└────┬─────┘                      └────┬─────┘
     │                                 │
     ▼                                 ▼
┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐
│ 500 iters│                      │  Single  │
│ of VGG   │                      │ Forward  │
│ backprop │                      │  Pass    │
└────┬─────┘                      └────┬─────┘
     │                                 │
~45 seconds                        ~16ms
     │                                 │
     ▼                                 ▼
┌──────────┐                      ┌──────────┐
│ Stylized │                      │ Stylized │
│  Output  │                      │  Output  │
└──────────┘                      └──────────┘

Beautiful but slow.               Fast enough for games.
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>The Speedup</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The tradeoff: you lose flexibility (one trained network per style) but gain
real-time performance. For a game engine plugin, that’s exactly the right deal.</p>
<p>Now I just had to build it, train it, export it to C++, link it against
libtorch, compile it as a GDExtension shared library, and hook it into
Godot’s rendering pipeline. Starting from this:</p>
<figure class="image-showcase" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i> <div class="showcase-frame" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>┘</span> <div class="featured-image" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i> <img src="/images/style-transfer/og_game.png" alt="the starting point — a crisp pixel-art platformer" loading="lazy" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i> <span class="image-label featured-label" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>the starting point — a crisp pixel-art platformer</span> </div>   </div> <figcaption class="showcase-caption" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i> <span class="annotation" data-astro-cid-ojnsp55i>the little robot, blissfully unaware it&#39;s about to become a Van Gogh</span> </figcaption> </figure> 
<p>In 45 days.</p>
<h2 id="the-model">The Model</h2>
<p>Both model variants are <em>tiny</em>. The slim model is <strong>110kB</strong> on disk.
The normal model is <strong>196kB</strong>. For reference, the JPEG header image
on most blog posts is bigger than the entire neural network.</p>
<h3 id="architecture">Architecture</h3>
<p>Both follow an encoder-residual-decoder pattern with only <strong>16 channels</strong>
throughout — compared to the 128 channels in Johnson et al.’s original.
The key difference between variants is depth:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
Slim (110kB, 1 res block):         Normal (196kB, 5 res blocks):

Input (3ch)                        Input (3ch)
    │                                  │
    ▼                                  ▼
┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐
│ Conv 3→16  │ ×3 layers           │ Conv 3→16  │ ×3 layers
│ stride 1,2,2                     │ stride 1,2,2
│ IN + ReLU6 │                     │ IN + ReLU6 │
└─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘
      │                                  │
      ▼                                  ▼
┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐
│  1× Res    │                     │  5× Res    │
│   Block    │                     │  Blocks    │
└─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘
      │                                  │
      ▼                                  ▼
┌────────────┐                     ┌────────────┐
│ Upsample   │ ×2 + final conv    │ Upsample   │ ×2 + final conv
│ 16→16→3    │                     │ 16→16→3    │
└─────┬──────┘                     └─────┬──────┘
      │                                  │
      ▼                                  ▼
Output (3ch)                       Output (3ch)

57kB VRAM  ·  52 FPS               129kB VRAM  ·  47 FPS
        (at 600×400)                        (at 600×400)
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>Slim vs Normal</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The choice of ReLU6 over standard ReLU is a mobile-optimization trick —
it clamps activations to [0, 6], which helps with quantization stability.
InstanceNorm with affine parameters handles the style-specific normalization.</p>
<h3 id="training">Training</h3>
<p>Trained on Pascal VOC 2012 (~17,000 natural images) for content, with
four style images: Monet, Udnie, Mosaic, and Van Gogh’s Starry Night.
5 epochs, Adam optimizer, learning rate 1e-3.</p>
<p>The loss function is where style transfer gets interesting. We use a
pre-trained VGG-16 as a “perceptual judge”:</p>
<p><strong>L_total = α·L_content + β·L_style + γ·L_tv</strong></p>
<p>With weights: <code>style_weight = 1e5</code>, <code>content_weight = 1e0</code>, <code>tv_weight = 1e-7</code>.</p>
<p>That style weight is 100,000× the content weight. You’re basically telling
the network: <em>“I care about looking like Van Gogh way more than I care about
looking like the original scene.”</em></p>
<p>The mathematical heart of style transfer is the Gram matrix — it captures
texture statistics by computing correlations between feature channels:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> gram</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">x</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    (bs</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> ch</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> h</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> w) </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> x</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">size</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">()</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    f </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> x</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">view</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(bs, ch, w</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">h)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    f_T </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> f</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">transpose</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">1</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">, </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">2</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    G </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> f</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">bmm</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(f_T)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> /</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> (ch </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> h </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> w)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> G</span></span></code></pre>
<p>Four lines. That’s what makes a photograph look like a painting.</p>
<h3 id="key-modifications">Key Modifications</h3>
<p>The original model was hardcoded for 256×256 inputs — useless for a game
with a dynamic viewport. I refactored it to be fully convolutional, replacing
hardcoded dimensions with relative scaling factors in the upsampling layers.
After training, models were exported to TorchScript via <code>torch.jit.trace</code>
and optimized with <code>torch.jit.optimize_for_inference()</code> for the C++ side.</p>
<p>I also evaluated both models against ~8,000 screenshots from MAME console
games — because if you’re building this for game engines, you should probably
test on actual game content, not just photos of dogs.</p>
<h2 id="the-bridge">The Bridge</h2>
<p>This is where it gets hairy. The goal: make a PyTorch model run inside
Godot’s render loop, every frame, without the engine noticing.</p>
<h3 id="the-scene-setup">The Scene Setup</h3>
<p>The Godot scene is deceptively simple:</p>
<figure class="ascii-diagram align-center" style="--diagram-font-size:12px" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <div class="diagram-frame" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6> <span class="corner corner--tl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┌</span> <span class="corner corner--tr" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┐</span> <span class="corner corner--bl" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>└</span> <span class="corner corner--br" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>┘</span> <pre class="diagram-content" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>
Node2D (root)
  │
  ├── Game (SubViewport)           ← the actual game runs here
  │     size: 512×256                 renders to a texture
  │
  ├── Sprite2D                     ← displays the stylized output
  │     position: (512, 299)
  │
  ├── MyCustomNode (GDExtension)   ← the magic middleman
  │     viewport_path: ../Game
  │     display_sprite_path: ../Sprite2D
  │
  └── Sprite2D2                    ← small preview of original
        texture: ViewportTexture(Game)
</pre> </div> <figcaption class="diagram-caption" data-astro-cid-jmmh6ey6>game_viewport.tscn</figcaption> </figure> 
<p>The GDScript that wires it up is exactly three lines:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="gdscript"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">extends</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> MyCustomNode</span></span>
<span class="line"></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">func</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> _ready</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">():</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">    set</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&quot;viewport_path&quot;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> NodePath</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&quot;../Game&quot;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">    set</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&quot;display_sprite_path&quot;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> NodePath</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-string-expression)">&quot;../Sprite2D&quot;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">)</span></span></code></pre>
<p>Everything else happens in C++.</p>
<h3 id="the-c-pipeline">The C++ Pipeline</h3>
<p>Every frame, <code>_process</code> grabs the viewport texture, runs it through
the model, and pushes the result back. Here’s the core of <code>process_image</code>,
stripped of debug logging:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="cpp"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">// 1. Convert RGBA → RGB</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">processed_image</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">-&gt;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">convert</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(Image</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">::</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">FORMAT_RGB8);</span></span>
<span class="line"></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">// 2. Borrow Godot&#39;s pixel data (no copy!)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">PackedByteArray data </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> processed_image</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">-&gt;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">get_data</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">();</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">torch</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">::</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">Tensor tensor </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> torch</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">::</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">from_blob</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    const_cast&lt;void*&gt;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">static_cast&lt;const</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> void*&gt;</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">data</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">ptr</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">()))</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    {height</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> width</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> 3</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">}</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> torch</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">::</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">kUInt8</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">to</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(torch</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">::</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">kFloat32);</span></span>
<span class="line"></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">// 3. Normalize with ImageNet stats</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">tensor </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> tensor </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">/</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)"> 255.0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">f</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">;</span></span>

<p>That <code>torch::from_blob</code> on line 5 is borrowing memory directly from
Godot’s <code>PackedByteArray</code>. No copy. The tensor just points at Godot’s
pixel buffer. It’s efficient and also slightly terrifying — if the
<code>PackedByteArray</code> gets garbage collected while the tensor is alive,
you’re reading freed memory. In practice it’s fine because the tensor
is consumed within the same function scope. But it’s the kind of thing
that keeps you up at night.</p>
<h3 id="the-build-system-nightmare">The Build System Nightmare</h3>

libtorch is an exercise in patience. The SConstruct file has paths like:</p>

<p>The CUDA story was even worse. Getting cuDNN to cooperate with both
libtorch and Godot’s OpenGL context required solving dependency conflicts
that would make a package manager weep. We eventually got GPU acceleration
working, but it was the single biggest time sink of the project.</p>
<h2 id="the-paradox">The Paradox</h2>
<p>Here’s where it gets interesting. We trained both models, benchmarked them
carefully, and discovered something that contradicts what you’d expect.</p>
<h3 id="the-numbers">The Numbers</h3>



































<table><thead><tr><th>Metric</th><th>Slim Model</th><th>Normal Model</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Disk Size</strong></td><td>110 kB</td><td>196 kB</td></tr><tr><td><strong>VRAM Usage</strong></td><td>57 kB</td><td>129 kB</td></tr><tr><td><strong>FPS</strong> (600×400)</td><td>52</td><td>47</td></tr><tr><td><strong>SSIM</strong> (structural similarity)</td><td>0.3047</td><td>0.2789</td></tr><tr><td><strong>LPIPS</strong> (perceptual quality)</td><td>0.6055</td><td>0.6125</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The normal model — five residual blocks, nearly double the parameters —
achieves <strong>lower total test loss</strong> (17.79 vs. 21.05). By every training
metric, it’s the better model.</p>
<p>But the slim model has <strong>higher SSIM</strong> and <strong>less temporal flickering</strong>
in actual gameplay.</p>
<p>The mathematically “better” model looks worse in practice.</p>
<h3 id="why-the-dumber-model-wins">Why the Dumber Model Wins</h3>
<p>The training-test gap tells the story. The slim model’s style loss jumps
from 2.00 (train) to 8.27 (test) — a big generalization gap. The normal
model is tighter: 1.64 to 4.71. Conventional wisdom says the normal model
generalizes better.</p>
<p>But in a game running at 60fps, <strong>temporal consistency matters more than
per-frame quality</strong>. The slim model’s simpler architecture produces more
consistent frame-to-frame outputs. The normal model’s extra capacity lets
it be more “creative” with each frame — which means more flickering when
the scene changes slightly between frames.</p>
<p>This is a genuinely useful insight: <strong>optimization metrics during training
don’t always align with quality in dynamic, real-time applications.</strong> Static
image loss functions can’t capture what it feels like to watch a game
where the art style jitters every frame.</p>
<h3 id="the-styles">The Styles</h3>
<p>I trained both models on four artistic styles: Van Gogh’s Starry Night
for swirling expressionism, Monet for soft impressionistic pastels, Udnie
for bold abstract patterns, and Mosaic for tile-like geometric segmentation.</p>
<p>All four produced visually distinct results on the 2D platformer demo.</p>

<h2 id="reflections">Reflections</h2>
<h3 id="what-worked">What Worked</h3>
<p>The feed-forward architecture was the right call from day one. The fully
convolutional refactor for dynamic input sizing was the most important
single modification — without it, the plugin would only work at one fixed
resolution. The GDExtension API was cleaner than I expected; Godot’s
node-based architecture mapped naturally onto the capture-process-display
pipeline.</p>
<p>And starting with the slim model turned out to be accidentally brilliant.
I spent time on the normal model assuming more parameters meant better
results, then discovered the slim model was better for the actual use case.
Sometimes the simplest architecture wins.</p>
<h3 id="whats-rough">What’s Rough</h3>
<p>Let me be honest about the state of this codebase.</p>
<p>The model path is hardcoded to <code>/home/sushanth/Dev/SML-Godot/ArtSynapse/model.pth</code>.
The build system has hardcoded paths to my local libtorch installation.
The FPS counter prints to stdout on <em>every single frame</em> — not every 20
seconds like the commented-out version suggests. The ONNX export path exists
but the inference function literally has a bare <code>return</code> with no value.</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> onnx_infer</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">path</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> img</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>

<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    input_name </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> sess</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">get_inputs</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">()</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">]</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">name</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    out </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> sess</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">run</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">None</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">, {input_name: img.</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">astype</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(np.float32)})</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">[</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">0</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">]</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">  # ← this returns None. ask me how I know.</span></span></code></pre>
<p>It’s a “works on my machine” binary. The cuDNN dependency means
building it on another system requires exactly the right CUDA toolkit
version, the right cuDNN version, and a willingness to read CMake error
messages for an afternoon.</p>
<h3 id="what-id-do-differently">What I’d Do Differently</h3>
<p>Profile GPU memory from day one instead of discovering the contention
between Godot’s renderer and PyTorch late in the project. Start with
the slim model instead of assuming the normal model would be better.
And tackle temporal consistency early — a simple exponential moving
average blend between consecutive stylized frames would have reduced
flickering significantly with minimal performance cost.</p>
<h3 id="future-directions">Future Directions</h3>
<p><strong>Dynamic model loading</strong> at runtime, so you could switch styles during
gameplay without restarting. <strong>Asset-specific styling</strong> — apply style
transfer to just the skybox or tilemap rather than the whole viewport.
A <strong>Colab training notebook</strong> so other developers could train custom
style models without setting up a local PyTorch environment.</p>
<h3 id="the-thing-about-course-projects">The Thing About Course Projects</h3>
<p>This was built for a Statistical Machine Learning course at ASU. The
kind of project where the scope starts reasonable and then you find
yourself debugging CUDA linker errors at 2am because you decided
“just hook a neural network into a game engine, how hard can it be?”</p>
<p>The model is 110 kilobytes. The build system that compiles it is
more complex than most production deployments I’ve worked on. The
hardcoded paths are embarrassing. The FPS logging is noisy. The
ONNX export is broken.</p>
<p>But it runs. A 2D platformer, rendered in Van Gogh’s style, at 52 frames
per second. You can jump, shoot, collect coins — and the whole world
looks like a painting.</p>
<p>For a course project built in 45 days, I’ll take it.</p> </div> </astro-slot></div></div><!--astro:end--></astro-island> </article> <nav class="project-nav" aria-label="Project navigation" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2> <div class="nav-divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2>

<p>Built an ML training pipeline for fine-tuning open-source LLMs on automated
code generation tasks, benchmarking against commercial models.</p>
<h2 id="the-problem">The Problem</h2>
<p>Current AI coding assistants show significant performance gaps between
commercial and open-source solutions. This project aimed to understand
and close that gap through targeted fine-tuning.</p>
<h2 id="data-processing-pipeline">Data Processing Pipeline</h2>
<p>Processed 11,000+ conversation turns from successful SWE-Bench solutions:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> process_conversation</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">conv</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    # Extract function calls and responses</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    turns </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> extract_turns</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(conv)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    # Custom tokenization for function-calling</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    tokens </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> tokenize_with_functions</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(turns)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> format_for_training</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(tokens)</span></span></code></pre>
<h2 id="model-architecture">Model Architecture</h2>
<p>Implemented custom tokenization for function-calling patterns on:</p>
<ul>
<li>Qwen2.5-Coder</li>
<li>Mistral-7B</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="results">Results</h2>
<p>Identified critical performance gaps between commercial and open-source
AI coding assistants, particularly in:</p>
<ul>
<li>Multi-file context handling</li>
<li>Error recovery strategies</li>
<li>Code explanation quality</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="reflections">Reflections</h2>
<p>The biggest challenge was handling the diversity of coding patterns across
different repositories and languages. Future work would focus on
domain-specific fine-tuning strategies.</p> </div> </astro-slot></div></div><!--astro:end--></astro-island> </article> <nav class="project-nav" aria-label="Project navigation" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2> <div class="nav-divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2>

class="prose" data-astro-cid-ovxcmftc> <h2 id="overview">Overview</h2>
<p>Walk My Block creates a living museum of your city. Users share audio logs
or polaroids tagged to their current location—content that only others
can discover by physically stumbling onto that spot.</p>
<h2 id="the-concept">The Concept</h2>
<p>Imagine walking down a quiet street and your phone buzzes. Someone recorded
a memory here three months ago. You listen. A stranger’s voice tells you
about the coffee shop that used to be on this corner, or the time they
proposed right where you’re standing.</p>
<h2 id="technical-implementation">Technical Implementation</h2>
<p>Built as a web application with Stadia Maps, featuring:</p>
<ul>
<li>Beautiful watercolor map overlay aesthetic</li>
<li>Location-tagged audio recording and playback</li>
<li>Polaroid-style photo uploads</li>
<li>Proximity-based content discovery</li>
<li>Offline-first architecture for spotty coverage areas</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="the-hackathon">The Hackathon</h2>
<p>Prototyped for Hacks-for-Humanity hackathon, where it was selected as an
org favourite. The judges loved the emphasis on human connection and
the way it encourages people to explore their neighborhoods.</p>
<h2 id="reflections">Reflections</h2>
<h3 id="what-made-it-special">What Made It Special</h3>
<ul>
<li>The serendipity of discovery</li>
<li>Low-friction content creation</li>
<li>The watercolor aesthetic softened the digital experience</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="future-possibilities">Future Possibilities</h3>
<ul>
<li>Curated walking tours by local historians</li>
<li>Integration with city archives</li>
<li>Ambient soundscapes for areas without user content</li>
</ul> </div> </astro-slot></div></div><!--astro:end--></astro-island> </article> <nav class="project-nav" aria-label="Project navigation" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2> <div class="nav-divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2>

class="_tabContent_1176a_65" role="tabpanel"><astro-slot> <div class="prose" data-astro-cid-ovxcmftc> <h2 id="overview">Overview</h2>
<p>Extended the xv6 educational operating system with production-grade features,
diving deep into how operating systems actually work under the hood.</p>
<h2 id="implemented-features">Implemented Features</h2>
<h3 id="multithreading">Multithreading</h3>
<p>Added POSIX-style threading support to xv6:</p>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="c"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">int</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> thread_create</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">void</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> (</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">fn)(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">void*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">)</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> void</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> *</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">arg) {</span></span>

<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    struct</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> proc </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">*</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">curproc </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> myproc()</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>

<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">        return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)"> -</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">1</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">;</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    // Share address space with parent</span></span>

<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">    </span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    // Set up stack and entry point</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    // ...</span></span>

<h3 id="on-demand-paging">On-Demand Paging</h3>
<p>Implemented lazy page allocation—pages are only allocated when actually
accessed, not when requested:</p>
<ul>
<li>Page fault handler for missing pages</li>
<li>Copy-on-write for fork optimization</li>
<li>Swap space management</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="bootloading">Bootloading</h3>
<p>Wrote a custom bootloader that:</p>
<ul>
<li>Loads kernel from disk</li>
<li>Sets up protected mode</li>
<li>Initializes page tables</li>
<li>Jumps to kernel entry point</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="trap-and-emulate-virtualization">Trap and Emulate Virtualization</h3>
<p>Implemented basic virtualization support allowing xv6 to host guest
operating systems through trap-and-emulate:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sensitive instruction trapping</li>
<li>Virtual memory management for guests</li>
<li>Device emulation layer</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="reflections">Reflections</h2>
<h3 id="what-i-learned">What I Learned</h3>
<ul>
<li>The elegance of Unix’s design decisions</li>
<li>How much complexity modern OSes hide from us</li>
<li>Why debugging kernel code requires patience</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="challenges">Challenges</h3>
<ul>
<li>Race conditions in the scheduler</li>
<li>Getting page table math right</li>
<li>The bootloader’s 512-byte limit</li>
</ul>
<p>This project gave me deep appreciation for systems programming and the
layers of abstraction we build on every day.</p> </div> </astro-slot></div></div><!--astro:end--></astro-island> </article> <nav class="project-nav" aria-label="Project navigation" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2> <div class="nav-divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-ab2n3vn2>

class="post-header" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4> <h1 data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>Building a Style Transfer Plugin for Godot</h1> <div class="title-line" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4></div> <div class="meta" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4> <span data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>January 7, 2025</span> <span class="separator" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>·</span> <span data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>2 min read</span> <span class="separator" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>·</span> <span data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4>c++, godot, ml, tutorial</span> </div> </header> <div class="prose" data-astro-cid-jxnjfbl4> <p>When I first started exploring neural style transfer, I didn’t expect to end up
knee deep in Godot’s rendering pipeline. But here we are.</p>
<p>The goal was simple: make a game look like a painting in real-time. The execution
was anything but.</p>
<h2 id="the-first-attempt">The First Attempt</h2>
<p>I started where anyone would: the original Gatys et al. paper¹. The results were
beautiful. The performance was not.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>“The best optimization is the one you don’t have to do.”</p>
<p>This kept echoing in my head as I stared at the profiler output.</p>
</blockquote>
<pre class="astro-code css-variables" style="background-color:var(--astro-code-background);color:var(--astro-code-foreground);overflow-x:auto" tabindex="0" data-language="python"><code><span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">def</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> style_transfer</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">(</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)">content</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> style</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">,</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-parameter)"> iterations</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">=</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-constant)">500</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)">):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-comment)">    # This took 45 seconds per frame</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    for</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> i </span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">in</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)"> range</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(iterations):</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-function)">        optimize_step</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-punctuation)">(content, style)</span></span>
<span class="line"><span style="color:var(--astro-code-token-keyword)">    return</span><span style="color:var(--astro-code-foreground)"> content</span></span></code></pre>
<p>45 seconds. Per frame. For a game targeting 60fps, I needed to be roughly
2,700 times faster.</p>
<h2 id="the-breakthrough">The Breakthrough</h2>
<p>The solution came from Johnson et al.’s feed-forward approach². Instead of
running an optimization loop at runtime, we train a neural network to perform
the style transformation in a single forward pass.</p>
<p>The tradeoff: we lose flexibility (one network per style) but gain
real-time performance.</p>
<h2 id="integrating-with-godot">Integrating with Godot</h2>
<p>Godot’s architecture made this surprisingly clean:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Viewport Capture</strong>: Hook into the rendering pipeline to grab frames</li>
<li><strong>PyTorch Bridge</strong>: C++ bindings to call the trained model</li>
<li><strong>Texture Injection</strong>: Push stylized frames back to the renderer</li>
</ol>
<p>The trickiest part was managing GPU memory—both Godot and PyTorch want
to own the graphics card.</p>
<h2 id="performance-tuning">Performance Tuning</h2>
<p>Getting to 60fps required several optimizations:</p>
<ul>
<li>Half-precision inference (FP16)</li>
<li>Async texture transfers</li>
<li>Resolution scaling based on GPU load</li>
<li>Frame interpolation for slower hardware</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="what-i-learned">What I Learned</h2>
<p>Building this taught me that game development is all about constraints.
You don’t need the perfect algorithm—you need one that’s fast enough
and looks good enough.</p>
<hr/>
<p>¹ Gatys, Ecker, Bethge. “A Neural Algorithm of Artistic Style.” 2015.</p>
<p>² Johnson et al. “Perceptual Losses for Real-Time Style Transfer.” 2016.</p> </div> </article>  </main> <footer class="footer" data-astro-cid-35ed7um5> <div class="divider" aria-hidden="true" data-astro-cid-35ed7um5>
